name: Kerbal Space Program
description: In Kerbal Space Program, take charge of the space program for the alien race known as the Kerbals. You have access to an array of parts to assemble fully-functional spacecraft that flies (or doesn’t) based on realistic aerodynamic and orbital physics.
minimum_requirements: OS:Windows 7 64-bit Processor:Core 2 Duo Memory:4 GB RAM Graphics:DX10 (SM 4.0) capable, 512MB VRAM Hard Drive:3 GB HD space
recommended_requirements: OS:Windows 10 64 bit Processor:Core i5 Memory:8 GB RAM Graphics:DX10 (SM 4.0) capable, 1GB VRAM Hard Drive:4 GB HD space

reviews.review_text: Actually helped me get my degree.  10/10

>Buy game in sale in 2013 >Spend 4 months attempting to get to the Mun >Spend the entire space program's budget on a Mun mission >Forgot solar panels >Jeb crashed due to lack of power. He is now stranded >Tell him I'm mounting a rescue mission >Get sidetracked flying planes to get more funds >Accidentally learn to dock >Somehow get to Duna >Mannded Duna landing and return >Make huge space station in Kerbin orbit >Turn it into a huge ship by docking engines >Fly to Jool and visit all the moons >Have spare fuel so decide to do a grand tour of the solar system >Finally done everything I came out to do. Start playing other games >Be me 2016 >Load up KSP after new update to check it out >Jeb still stranded on Mun 10/10
Got to the moon with 2 kerbals, half way back to kerbin I realized I left Bill on the Mun.  10/10

I have been playing this game for a very long time. Very easy to get into, very hard to master.   It is not a simulation by any means, but that doesn't mean you won't still learn a lot about rocketry, and the things which NASA and the folks who fly in those crazy contraptions have to deal with.   The Community as well is extremely nice, and extremely active. With a mass amount of mods for the game, which allows you to really customize it to your liking (Much like Elder Scrolls games are).   On top of that, they are also moving it to Unity 5 (If they havn't already at the time you're reading this in the future), meaning the limitation on mods will be quite literally... limitless.   That with Multiplayer to boot! (Coming Soon as well with Unity 5).   -----------------------------  The game itself has 3 modes.   Career: Which pits you against your mind. Balancing income from successfull missions, reputation, and science. Failed missions could cost you big, and learning how to create a more cost friendly ship to do the same job could save you bundles. Use Science to unlock new parts on the tech tree, to push your exploration even farther.   Science: Same as Career but without the reputation and Money.   Sandbox: Like all Sandboxes.. Everything is tehre from the start, no money, science or anything else, Just build and have fun.   -------------------------------  What you do in the game is open ended. IT's your choice. Build what you want, and fly it anywhere you want (Or anywhere it can go). There are many many entire different planets to explore, moons, asteroids, etc. A fully open ended solar system.   Taking off from Kerbin, flying through the upper atmosphere, and breaking through into space is seemless and a wonderful excitement when you do it for your first time without the ship exploding.   From there, going to another planet, landing anywhere you want on it and exploring it, then coming back and hoping you have the right trajectory to burn safely through the kerbin atmosphere as flames fly up around your ship.. epic.    5 Tests launching rockets that failed: 2,000,000   Launched a rocket to the Mun, but couldn't return: 400,000 + 1 stranded Kerbal   Attempted a rescue Mission with the same result: 450,000 + another stranded Kerbal   Finally reaching the Mun, and returning back safely in the water: Priceless

Kerbal Space Program, at least to me is the king of simulation games. While I play numerous others (such as Farming Simulator) they don’t seem to hit every mark in that field. KSP, while challenging at first is the one that throws everything that happens in reality at the player, and force them to deal with it. While a game like Farming Sim only really requires you to keep an eye on fuel or some crops, KSP requires that you maintain a healthy supply of necessities ranging from fuel and electricity, to a satellite connection back home. But the part of the game that truly shines is the feeling you get when you first land on the Mun. A friend who gave the game a shot said   Originally posted by  Bacaber :
This game made me discover Scott Manley. 10/10 - Would discover Scott Manley again.

This is one of my favourite games. Its simply amazing.  KSP is walking the fine line between a space sciency simulation and a comicly slapstick just for fun and giggles game.  Its harsh and unforgiving in the beginning, expecting you to know about the basic science of rocketry or fail over and over until you get it on your own. (Watch ScottManley tutorials if you want a head start)  I had trouble in the beginning even getting into orbit around the planet (or keeping my rocket upright on the way there) - but now I am planing missions to other planets, landing and returning - sending unmanned rovers to explore - or even bringing asteroids back home.  800 hours in and I feel like I am still just at the beginning.  »Mün or bust« - unknown (prob. Jebediah Kerman or KurtJMac)
Picked up a copy during its early access, have been in love with it since.

In my Steam library, there are about a half dozen games that are in a special category called 'All Time Greats'. Civ IV is there. Skyrim is in there.   KSP is in there.  Note my play time does NOT include the 50-100 hours I put in before the game was ever on Steam.  Simply one of the best products in the last decade, KSP is not your typical 'game'. It's a software toy. You tinker. You experiment. You adjust. You tweak. And you have a grand time doing it. KSP is not a game that is going to hold your hand and help you build a super-deluxe space rocket that can go to the Mun or Eve with ease. If it did that KSP would not be any fun. Besides, if someone wants that Buzz Aldrin's Space Race is available for sale on Steam.   Instead, you get better at the game. You develop an understanding of Newtonian Physics - more than you ever thought you would. You build massive rockets and undertake interesting expeditions. You'll grin the first time you get a rocket into orbit. You'll pump your fist when you land on the Mun for the first time. And you'll continue having fun.  What are you waiting for? Go buy it!
I'll never forget what my estranged father said to me when he saw me playing KSP.    That's pretty cool...yeah.   Thanks Dad. Here look, you can see the orbit's  periapsis....dad?   Oh, bye...
R.I.P to the hundreds of Kerbins who died in tragic but mostly avoidable accidents.

This game... Day 1: I'll buy it Day 2: so parachutes fire at the same time as engines? huh Day 3: Oh thats how you stage Day 4: There are other planets? Day 5: ill go to mars! Day 6: how do i orbit? Day 7: i killed all my kerbals. Day 8: *leaves game* Day 45: You can get new dudes?!?!? Present date: MOD IT TILL IT BREAKS!!!

I have a love-hate relationship with this game. It's the most rewarding game I've ever played. It's also made me want to kill myself when I forget to add parachutes and don't realize until I'm re-entering Kerbin.  I love this game. **** this game.
KERBAL GUIDE TO SPACE

I decided to not do ANY tutorials when I started playing this game.   35 hours later I was in orbit.   38 hours in, I figured out how to match my orbit with the Mun.   At 40 hours I got caught in the Mun's orbit.   At 42 hours I hit the Mun.   At 43 hours I accidentally hit space and diconnected my final rocket stage when I meant to increase throttle.  44/10 would play again.

What starts out as a simple, often hilarious; almost lego-like rocket/spaceplane builder has an astounding depth when you look into the possibilities.   The game features a great incentive for advancing your ambitions, science. Science is spent on new technology and parts for bolder missions, and is earned by pushing your boundaries. First, you can explore around you. Take samples, and crew reports from your cute crew of little green simpletons, then maybe you take a simple rocket to outer atmosphere for the first time, take a crew report and get home alive with a nifty parachute.. and Bam! More science. A new part, and the plot thickens..  KSP begins as a goofy tinkering tool with rockets and develops into a full-blown space exploration and research SIM. Getting a rock sample from the moon may be one of your hardest gaming achievements, as it was for me, but doing it brings reward like little else. The planning, the development and trial/error makes KSP a great learning tool. It's even NASA approved. It uses real world physics and simulated drag for winged aircraft. It uses realistic orbital-mechanics for planitary manuevers, and players use realistic many real-life elements mission planning.   Buy it for your kids, buy it for yourself. They'll enjoy goofing and experimenting; they might even get serious about it. Same goes for you; you will enjoy at least a few experimental flights/missions. Especially if they end in a giant explosion, as many early flights will. After that you might have a success or two, maybe a simple contract or research mission turns out to be easy and you start learning. Soon you'll have dreams of the stars.  *****

After playing for 72 hours...  The funnest part of this game, is building the rockets of any design I can think of, testing them. (Go to launch... topple over and go boom... darn it, try again...) The graphics are pretty good. Some reason the crew is hard on my system when building the crafts, had to turn them off.  One thing I do not understand is why your craft is desroyed even when hitting water at 5m/s via parachute, only thing to survive is the cockpits. (not a game breaker, just know the water is off limites in the game)  ... Patience is required while playing ... It takes a long time to get across the oceans to land your craft at desired locations. You have to be careful when using the speed up if flying a plane. It can cause you to loose/gain altitude without touching the controls.  The arodynamics of the game are increadable. Durring one of my missions, altidude required for testing an item had put me in space, I managed to test it, but was out of fuel, and still orbiting, I almost restarted but chose to see if the close path was close enough to barely skim the atmosphere, and sure enough, angled the heat sheild to push the module deeper into the atmosphere, reducing orbit considerably, the next pass was slow enough to actually stay in the atmosphere, again, angled it to push it in deeper. The angle was so good, I was able to open the chutes at about 1900m and land on top of a mountain.  Neucances of the game, the physics engine does something strange, causing the ship to stop flowing with the rest of the system, the ship dangles there, it's orbit doesn't move, but the planet does, if left alone long enough, the orbit no longer orbits the planet, but the ship still hangs there. Other times the ship suddenly disintigrates right after a 'warp time' menuver. More than one occation on a load, the vessel is well belloe the 0m mark, on water it breaks the ship into pieces, and only specific pieces float to the surface. On land, only the pieces that register as above 0.000m is not instantly destroyed. These sorts of things make it difficult to play career mode. Occational crash to desktop, without known reasons, sometimes it says it has crashed, and to tell them about it, yet doesn't say what to do with a folder. I got the game through steam, will be nice when they have an update to fix known bugs. (Even so, I still recomend the game.)  .... Bottom Line ... I am enjoying the game. Devs keep up the great work.

It turned me into an 8-year old boy who just saw his first rocket launch. I had a birthday cake with rockets on it. It's easily the best game I've ever played, and it just gets better with every new version.

I have much more hours in this game, I bought it before it was even on Steam.   Kerbal Space Program is a space-agency simulator where you control the agency itself and the actual Kerbonauts (astronauts). There are three gamemodes, career (you manage the actual agency with funds, popularity/approva, and research tech), science (same as before but just research) and sandbox with no limitations but there's almost no agency mechanics. Although because of that sandbox may sound like a lesser mode, the agency mechanics are really secondary.  The main gameplay is being the actual Kerbonauts and performing the mission, which you yourself can determine or you can take a contract. However building the rocket (or spaceplane) is just as important as actually flying it. There's a whole solar-system for you to explore, complete with asteroids and moons for some of the planets. Some of the planets even have irrational orbits, and some of those have moons with an irrational orbit to the planet. The game is realistic enough to be somewhat educational but loose enough to be a very fun game.   The game is somewhat difficult due to the loose-realism, but that is a good thing for myself. I'd rather a game be too hard (this game definitely isn't) than be too easy. Everytime I start a new save, I learn something new along the way everytime. Whether it's a more efficient way to get into orbit, faster way to dock, or even a way to use less parts for a rocket. I always learn something new, and I love that.   Also, KSP is one of the few games ever to exit early-access and actually be complete with no major bugs. That's dedication.

If you have even a remote interest in space and space travel, buy this game. Seriously. It's worth it.  There's a learning curve but when you learn how to play, it's very satisfying and rewarding completing contracts and exploring the solar system.  There's a huge modding community as well so you can make the experience even better with Realism Overhaul & Real Solar System to get as close to real life rocket ships as possible. (+hundreds of other mods like SpaceX rockets and other real life rockets and engines and graphic improvement mods.)  Seriously, this is one of the best games I've ever played. The development team (SQUAD) is very active and transparent with the community.

How did i not write a review for the great game. I think it amazing to get to experience space travel with todays tech imaginations. I was born too late to discover the earth and too soon explore the stars. For now i have the internet with cat pictures and ksp
Create a plane, doesnt fly. Make a car, goes to space. 10/10 would space again.

Build. Fly Dream.  One of the best sandbox games in this decade of sandbox games. You are given a whole star system open to exploration; Mun, Duna, Laythe, all these planets are yours, except Eve, attempt no landing there. However each trip has new challenges and the game does not hold your hand through them you will run out of fuel, burn up in re-entry, and explode and explode and explode. That rush you feel though when you finally plant that flag and safely return to Kerbin is incomparable.  This is the gateway drug to space. Nasa, Esa, and Roscosmos should pay squad for recruiting their next generation of scientists, engineers, and pilots.

Why are you still not playing it?   This game is as pivotal to sandbox games as was minecraft , but in a completely different department - depth.  Simulated solar system, chance to experience and learn real (almost - still cut some corners - no la-grande points, orbits are mostly radial without additional simulation after a swing, but none the less) rocket science. Sense of achievement with this game is as huge as in dwarf fortress, when through error, misery, failure, countless tries you finally get your ♥♥♥ to <s>mars</s> Duna. And it only goes up from there.  And then there are mods. My. GOD. Modding scene for this game gone above and beyond:  You want attachment systems? Sure.  You want to mine? Since 1.0 - embedded, but there are also kethane and open resource system.  You want to build rockets on distant planets - sure - Extraplanetary launchpads got you covered.  You want even more? How about warp drive and additional systems mod?  Want more realism? TAS Mods got you covered with food, water and waste resources.  Want working actuators? Infernal robotics got you covered.  I got more than 600 hours of gameplay out of this game (300+ on steam, 300 prior) and it still has a little bit more to offer, and with newer mods coming around - it is always fun to occasionally get back to it.  This game is like a good song or a good movie - memorable, can be watched/listened a dozen times and never gets old.  So, once again, why are you still not playing it?

The best simulation game I've ever played! The stock game is amazing enough for trying to get to orbit, and other planets (very hard, still havent landed everywhere in one trip.. after 1000 hours). Also boats and land vehicles if you're into that (on other planets too why not?). But with mods... it can become every other sim game youve ever wanted! And a handy community run mod database and manager (CKAN) to make it easy!  Flight combat sim: install realistic aerodynamic mod and weapons mod to make your own F15s fight your own Su-27s (FAR and BDarmory).   Colony building: there are life support and resource collecting mods that challenge you to scan for the right site and use resources on any of the planets to sustain a colony of kerbals; even manufacture new parts there (MKS, TAC lifesupport, extraplanetary launchpads, scansat, remotetech).   Hardcore realistic simulation? Theres a mod that converts the stock star system to a 1:1 scale replica of the solar system, with real-life satellite data used (real solar system, realism overhaul, probably more mods - these are too scary for me). Realism overhaul I think uses historical rocket data so you can create saturn-V replicas with the accurate fuel mixtures and everything!   Or go the other way and get futuristic mods to create antimatter powered near-light speed craft to visit entire other solar systems (nearfuture, KSPinterstellar)!   And with the new 1.1 release on Unity 5, you may actually be able to use these mods without running out of memory!  Between the great modding community and active devs (for over 5 years!) this game will continue to get better and better, so even at full price of $40 its a great deal!
i personally do not like this game, however i do recommend it because if you like space craft building sims then you will enjoy this. Great sim just im not the target audience.
Imagine the movie Apollo 13, but as a video game. It is intense as balls.  Plus, after going to the moon a couple times, you'll understand more about spaceflight than all of your friends combined!

An amazing flight/space simulator, with amazing depth and detail, as well as vast scope. From building space-pleanes(and not-so-space planes), to hi-tech rockets to land on everything from the mun to Dres, as well as do orbital science, this game is a incredible space program simulator.  In addition, it is fully modable(and has a huge modding community with hundreds if not thousands of mods), and has cooperated with big-name groups like the ESA and NASA.  I highly recommend buying this, and i can only say, there is no such thing as to many struts, and check(and then RE-check) your stages. And then check them for a third time, just to be sure........  Easily, 11/10  Addendum:  With the update to 1.0, this game only gets better, They redid the atmospheric model, tweaked all the parts to be more realistic, and added tons of new parts to the game. And of course, if its something they didnt include, you can be sure some modder on Curse or the KSP forums made a mod for it. It is so expansive, i cant even go over all of it here. Check out Scott Manley's YouTube channel for in-depth learning on how to play, and just get right into it, it is well worth the buy, and the time.   20/10.
There are no words to explain how much I love this game. How can such a simple thing be so awesome. Brings out my nerdy side and makes me wish I could go back in time and study phyics.
A game you can easily spend 2000 hours plus on

I came to this came on the wave of Reddit hype a few years ago since then, I have: put it down, deleted, reintalled, flung mice around my room, printed off screenshots and actually shouted in triumph upon landing on the Mun. The worth of a game, a film, of art in general comes down to the emotional response it elicits. KSP has caused me actual ♥♥♥♥ing trauma, total euphoria, crushing despondancy, childlike wonder, intellectual overreach and many other feelings beyond mere words. Building a rocket, blowing up said rocket on the launch pad, fixing the staging, running out of fuel before circularising, consulting our Lord Scott Manley, circularising, achieving orbit and just staring out the window at tiny Kerbin before burning retrograde and coming back home.   To recommend this game, is to recommend the spectrum of life's emotions.

KSP is a game in which you run a space center, build spacecrafts, launch them and fly them to explore the Kerbin system.   Your space empire could be built on a plethora of crew sacrifice, and it will be tedious process to learn to fligth freely. But nothing could bring you so much sense of achievement than standing on the soil of other celestial objects. Only the most intellectual and hardworking one will be awarded.  The most attracting portion of this game is building mindblowing spacecrafts and flying them in the space. When you play in career mode, you will have to consider whether it could fly your crew members back to Kerbin safely and whether you could afford it. Every spacecraft is a essense of your mind and your knowledge about astronomy, physics, aerodynamics, etc.  10/10 Play this game and kill Jedebiah again!

It's a game that challenges you to know math, physics and be very creative. If you fail, you'll have glorious explosions or forever be lost in space. If you succeed, you'll be on path to conquer an entire solar system.
A must for anyone interested in rockets. A super-deep game, with hilarious moments.
This game is the best game about space exploration on steam and probably on the internet.

I can't describe enough how much this game is awesome. It is frustrating annoying and makes you cry, but first time you land on the moon you are hooked for life.  11/10  Srpski - ljudi igra je odlična, nećete pogrešiti sa kupovinom, isplati se svaki dinar.
The amount of kerbals I have got stuck in space because i ran out of fuel..... In all seriousness thouugh, great game to pass the time.  11/10
Want to play a airplane sim? KSP. Space Sim? KSP. Moon lander sim? KSP. Anything related to physics sim? KSP.
It's ok
Because of this game I nailed the astrophysics section of my GCSE exam and ended up with an A*. Enough said.

AMAZING game. Do you like flying? Do you like space? Ever wanted to build planes and spaceships? Then allow yourself. I\'ve learned so much about launching crafts into orbit, getting to planets, the calculations, OH what I have learned. And the fun I\'ve had while doing it!   You\'ll spend a half an hour building a spacecraft and making sure its 100% set and ready to get put into orbit and complete its objective. Then you\'ll get to launch and control your craft through the atmosphere and into the galaxy laid out before you. Two moons orbit your planet, more planets lay beyond yours, each with different gravity and temperatures and atmospheres.  If you want a game about space and building your own craft and controlling them? Do it. SO worth it. I\'ve even found making my own jets and flying within the atmosphere fun and educational all in one. If you have a creative kid, or one who loves spaces? Do it.  It has a sandbox mode, build and fly whatever you want, or you can take on missions and slowly proceed through the various parts and completing different objectives.  Downsides? Only jets for inner atmosphere, no propellers in the vanilla game (with mods you can get some, but they aren\'t 100%), no submarine crafts to my knowledge, but \'water craft\' and seaplanes... errr seajets are able to be made.  Overall 100%, get it! Try it out at the very least!
Best game of my life

My lego kit meets universesandbox in an enjoyable physics engine. - This game is seriously good, and teaches you about things like orbital mechanics, physics, creativity and persistance. The mod community is amazing, and with the diversity of mods out there; you can change your gameplay hundreds of times. If you like anything about space, this is as close as you can get on steam to fulfilling your lifelong dream to be an astronaut, physicist, rocket engineer, astrobiologist, chemical engin... okay you get it. Watch some twitch streams, or play the demo and be prepared to become obsessed.
Amazing game. It have its flaws, but it is not important, because this game is able to show people what is real space ships and how it works using an orbital mechanics.

KSP is a great game if you love to crash, build, or fly things. (Or if you want to unleash your creativity)  (Or even keep a population in check :))  And with the official release of KSP, the game has become a lot more fun since the earlier updates.  I totally recommend the game.  12/10
One of the best games i've ever played. It has combined my love for all things science fiction and the joy of creating something of your own.  10/10, a real blast!

Kerbal Space Program is a game thats easy to play hard to master, understanding Delta-v, Gravity assists, rendezvous and many other technical and physic base technique. But man oh man it's fun. I can only play it for short bursts due to the fact that it strains my mind, but they are rewarding for the effort and psyche that you put into it. I recommend reading the in game Wiki or watching Youtube videos before frustrating yourself. If you are a enthusiast on the subject of aerospace then I implore you to try this game.

I'm proud to see a early access finish also it's a great game trying to get your ship into space and keeping it there is very fun :D.
My hours on Kerbal describe how good this game is.  Jeb commands you to buy it
One of the best sandbox games even if you're not trying to reach space.

This is such a little gem. Sure, there's a learning curve to it, but that's part of the appeal. Where else can you learn comprehensive orbital mechanics, complicated calculus concepts, and simplistic aeronautical engineering all while enjoying satisfying cartoonish antics if you happen to mess up? Nowhere else. This is a beautiful thing. I'm so glad it exists.
if you grew up on legos, mythbusters and flight simulators, play this.

This game is for every person eager to join the adventures of space, no matter if you can't get there. You only have to sit down and launch KSP and launch a rocket into space. It is probably one of the best simulator games out there and has top marks from the reviewers. If you don't like the rocket aspect of the game you can also build spaceplanes. I give this game a 11/10 rating and I hope you would do the same. Happy launchings!

With gametime over 500 hours I thougt I should write a review. I've had this game since it was an early access game, and I still enjoy it a lot. Some mods should be essential such as 'Renaissance Compilation', it makes the world a lot more realistic and enjoyable. It is difficult for everybody the first time, but with some practise you'll gain experience beyond your imagination. I was so proud the first time I landed on the mun that I snapchatted my friends even if it rolled over to the side. Now I am a quite experienced player and I think almost everything feels too easy. So don't refund the game just because it is hard.
Great game, especially since 1.0 fixed a lot of the framerate lag on my pc. I would recommend this too anyone who has a lot of patience and likes space.
KSP is a magnificent game. I could play it all day.

This is one of those rare games that didn't use early access as an excuse for the game being ♥♥♥♥. Even in early alpha the game had more features than many fully released titles, and yet more keeps coming. Really, I cannot recommend this game enough. If you have a spare £30 lying around then I encourage you to invest the money in this game as you will not be dissapointed. However, if you are the type of person that easily gives up on a game, do not but this, as it has a VERY steep learning curve and you should not expect to be travelling to the moon in your first vouage. Apart from that, 10/10.
As someone studying astrophysics. This is a whole heap of fun! I recommend it to anyone!!

Best Value i have ever gotten in a game. If you like Building things and are interested in the least about space and Flight. Get THIS GAME. Think i paid 20 dollare for this game..compared to time played...

I've been playing KSP for a few weeks at this point and have made it all the way to obriting the Mun.  Each successful mission has been an ever more impressive triumph which requires a greater depth of understanding and strategy, in asset allocation, construction, mission planning, and execution.  I just went skydiving for the first time today. It was beyond words. Amazingly I followed every step in sequence at exactly the right altitudes without my instructor having to remind me. All while screaming toward the ground at up to 120 miles an hour. My instructor was so impressed that she let me land us at the end of the parachute coast after free fall.  After it was over I couldn't shake the feeling that I had just successfully landed on the Mun.  No game should be so good that you land from a skydive you feel the same exhileration and pride you do from playing it.   A trip to the Mun is way more exciting than 'a trip to Pittsburg', and it's worth the hard knocks to figure out how to get there.

-Tried to get a Kerbal named Jebediah into the orbit of Kerbin. -Ended up orbiting the Sun and almost hit the Mun before I got to the Sun. -Decided to let him orbit the Sun. -'Do it for science,' I thought. -Couple hours later I decide to check on Jebediah (the pilot of the failure/success of a vessel). -The tracking station could not locate him. -My guess is that he died for the advancement of Kerbal science and for the betterment of his   kin.   10/10 would lose best pilot in the name of science again.
This game is a right brained creative types dream come true!!

This Is The Best Space Game Ever
Despite having had a lifelong love of rockets and space, I learned more in 2hrs playing this game about space travel than I thought possible.

This game is great, it has practically infinite replayability, and also appeals to an audience from newbies who just mess around to professionals who’ve crunched all the numbers. Also great modding community.
is a good game but im here for the steam awards, read some other review.

I will keep this review short. It a great game and you all should own one copy of the game. I have been comming back to this game for years and it was awesome back in the days where the only thing you could do was build a rocket measly selection of parts and go to space. Not land on the Mün or anything. Just go in to space. And it keep being awesome to this day with the great support it has gotten from it developers. This is a shining example of what a early access game can be with a lot of charm and creativity.

Cool game. Vanilla is fun, but science grinding in career gets dull after a while.  One of about 3 games made in Unity that I actually like.  Has some system flaws: basically it loads EVERYTHING into RAM during the startup meaning it can take a looongggg time. I\'m running realism overhaul + real solar system + a couple more mods and it takes 25 minutes to start up. That said, to go all console peasant and justify this, the load time commits me to the game so when I get frustrated (every time) I just try again until it works.  To date that strategy isn\'t working, I\'ve tried 25 times to put a simple satellite into orbit, and failed every single time. Tons of fun though.

What's there to say? There is no standard by which to judge this trailblazer. It's a unique experience and educational to boot. The beggining may be hard but once you finally manage to land on the Mun for the first time you'll know what this game is about.

If you like space and building things, you'll like Kerbal Space Program. The graphics are mostly so-so, but gameplay is excellent. There's no artificial sense of achievement; you set your own goals and work hard to achieve them. At first, the game will feel really difficult, but as you master the real physics behind the game, you'll be able to go bigger and grander. The base game feels complete, but mods add a lot more to the experience.   Overall, an amazing game with tremendous replay value. 10/10

Huge graveyards of dead astronauts. Piles of debris lying around and orbiting on planets far away. Abandoned or crashed rovers on the moon. Craters from incorrectly calculated landings.   Many have tried and many have failed.  The fun and excitement of Kerbal Space Programm is the progress and possibility to engineer new ways to finally achieve goals. Optimize your rockets and try different propulsion systems. Still need more fuel? Just transport a spacestation into an orbit and be able to dock and refill.   Judging on the goals you have set, you can always be a winner.  And when you have achieved 'anything' there is a huge modding community.  10/10

“Look again at that dot. That's here. That's home. That's us. On it everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every 'superstar,' every 'supreme leader,' every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there-on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.  The Earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena. Think of the endless cruelties visited by the inhabitants of one corner of this pixel on the scarcely distinguishable inhabitants of some other corner, how frequent their misunderstandings, how eager they are to kill one another, how fervent their hatreds. Think of the rivers of blood spilled by all those generals and emperors so that, in glory and triumph, they could become the momentary masters of a fraction of a dot.  Our posturings, our imagined self-importance, the delusion that we have some privileged position in the Universe, are challenged by this point of pale light. Our planet is a lonely speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. In our obscurity, in all this vastness, there is no hint that help will come from elsewhere to save us from ourselves.  The Earth is the only world known so far to harbor life. There is nowhere else, at least in the near future, to which our species could migrate. Visit, yes. Settle, not yet. Like it or not, for the moment the Earth is where we make our stand.  It has been said that astronomy is a humbling and character-building experience. There is perhaps no better demonstration of the folly of human conceits than this distant image of our tiny world. To me, it underscores our responsibility to deal more kindly with one another, and to preserve and cherish the pale blue dot, the only home we've ever known.”   - Carl Sagan
I crashed on the Mün, wrecking my ship, but the crew survived. I mounted a rescue mission, but they crashed too. They live there now.
Shuttles are fun.

Let's just say I didn't think I would spend as much time as I have on this game when I bought it. You might think 'how is this game fun?', but once you start playing it, you'll understand. It's ridiculously addicting figuring out why your rocket flipped out in the first minute of flight. Or just trying to deliver 'one more module' to your space station before you call it a night.  First off, I recommend career mode to start. This is the best addition this game has had in my opinion. I personally love having goals in a game and this provides it, since you start off with very few parts and simples missions. In a way, career mode it loosely teaches you how to build better and better rockets as you unlock more parts.  A side effect of playing this game is you will have a vastly improved understanding of orbital mechanics and how space flight even works. It's also fun to get your friends to try and play it and watch them crash their rockets!

Most likely the best space simulator ever made.  While there is a bit of a learning curve and it may take a while to actually be successful and good at the game, I do still highly recommend this to anyone with an itch or desire to build things and explore outer space. (Some youtube videos by Scott Manley or someone similar will help out greatly.)  And with it finally releasing in 1.0, it is now full with tons of various features and things you can do.  Lets also not forget that also the fun and exploration is near truly endless with the addition of mod support.  Graphics: 8.5/10  Audio: 8.75/10  Gameplay/Replay-ability: 9.25/10  Interface/Controls: 9  Mod Support: 9.25/10  Overall, I give this game a 9/10.
Exceptional game but the 40 dollar asking price is to high. Other than that with all the mods you can install you can really turn this game into something great.

An entertaining space program simulator with endless replayability. Easy to get started, but challenging to master, KSP is sure to deliver countless hours of gameplay while you construct and fly your spacecraft into orbit and onto other planets and moons. This has to be one of the toughest and most rewarding games I have ever played!  If you like being creative and working on your engineering skills, this is the game for you.  You will celbrate all your victories from your first launch through the atmosphere of Kerbin to your first safe return from the surface of Eve (which requires every braincell you have ;-) ) There is always something new to do and new ways to do the same things. Wanna build a space station aorund the Jupiter equivalent Jool? Go and do it. Wanna build an ion-powered space bike? Go and do it. Wanna build a base on the moon? Go and do it.   An extensive modding community keeps this game exiting and I guarantee you will return to it, even after 100+ hours.   Highly addictive and highly recommendable.

There is so much to do in Kerbal Space Program (KSP) that this review will not even begin to break past the delicious sugary strawberry decoration on the top of the Creme Brulee that is KSP.   I have 134 hours played and have made it through 1/10th of the game so far. You can LITERALLY spend months playing this game........well unless you're some kind of mindless shooter drone player. The multiple modes available can help you understand the game and provide the goal/purpose of the game despite there being no storyline what so ever (lets be honest most people only get 5-20 hours out of a storyline anyways).   I'm done describing.........JUST BUY THE GAME. Trust me it's complete worth it. Seriously I've spent 134 hours playing it and I constantly tell friends on Steam 'F OFF I'm playing KSP trying to get to planet 'X'!'   I have yet to play the full release version but I'm way more hours in than when I made this review. Free Mode and Campaign are AWESOME! If you're one of those 'earn it' gamers then you will love campaign. If you just want to screw around then Free Mode will keep you busy for weeks.

This has to be by far a perfect example of what an early access title can bloom into: a fully fleshed complete experience, where I never felt like I was being cheated in any way. This game has regular updates which shows the support of the developers, and just helps give you something new to do every time you open the game. I utterly love this game and the fact that i can go from building interplanetary colony ships to a jet powered boat that can break the sound barrier. The mod support is also an amazing part of the game, and will also ensure the longevity of this amazing title. So a tl;dr for those of you who are lazy :P  Pros: - Sandbox environment where you can explore an entire solar system - Fully simulated physics, in atmosphere and in vacuum - Amazing modular rocket/plane building - Constant support from dev team - Extreme amount of content for price - Modding support - Amazing community - KERBALS!  Cons: - Runs in 32 bit causing instability issues, especially when running mods  So all in all i honestly rate this game 9.5/10

Ammended review:  I bought this when it first appeared on here and the modding community was brand new and not yet on Curse (which sucks, but oh well). It's cool to see it become this massive success story and I decided to edit the review after seeing it's about to go official.  I put 250 hours into it before I felt I could play other games again, and all told I've spent probably 300 hours in KSP. This is the best sandbox game in existence right now and if even a tiny part of you likes space, science, physics or launching rockets, buy this now. I got it for $11 I think back then, but I'd gladly pay $50.   I feel sad for people who don't love this game.

This game has been the best game I have ever played. I love space, and I thoroughly recomend this game to anyone who loves a great space sim that is both simple enough to be fun, but complex enough to keep interest. I have played it for hours and was never bored. Helping little green men explore their solar sytem has never been so amazing. With so many great mods and addons, this game just can't be beat. Firstly, Ive followed this game since it was early acces, its been a great 2 years watching this game grow, to see that some early acces games ARE worth it and these developers DESERVE evey cent i poured into this game. They have my full support and they, unlike others on steam, have never let me down.  Now for the review: This game is amazing, your in charge of your own space program, and, if you wish, can manage cash, research, reputation, and so on, to hire better crew, purchase new parts (through a tech tree) and explore the great solar system of Kerbol (the Sun, for us humans). this solar system is mutch like ours, with a few differences (more moons here and there, and less moons there and there, etc).   Its a great physics space game that dosnt ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t you. You have all the tools (almost, still waiting for the Canadarm and so on) that real space programs have IRL, and with them do what so many dreamed of doing, massive space stations, colonization of other planets, mid trip refueling from planets (this was one of the major reasons why water on Mars was a great discovery, its not all about life, its also about using planets as stepping stones. I could write pages and pages of the features you get with this game but that wouldnt exactly be a review.  If you want, u can also just have all the stuff there in sandbox, which is also fun, but more daring players will want the extra challenge; to see the potential of every indvidual part. THHIS game, my freinds and Frenemies, is amazing, and its worth its price, which for what it offers most would call a bargin, and you will NOT regret buying this game.   Congratualtions, Devs of KSP and everyone else at SQUAD. You guys are the best, thank you for the amazing game, and we all look forward with great excitment to the next patch, as we have since early acces :)

played 13 hours ON THE DEMO played more 113 hours online and anothe 40 or so offline (AT WORK ETC) best £20 ever spent on a game fo shizzle what i love is there is so much content, if you are some epic badass nerd at rocket science (i am now!) and you can play this well, there is a TON of planets to visit... and each planet has its own subsystem! and each system has its own characteristics! there are changes with gravity/gas/athmosphere/physics EVERYTHING AND MORE!  and if you arent that good at it-lets be honest... most of us arent... then you still have a lot of fun messing about, blowing stuff up, making rockets and landing on the mun etc! i have learnt so much playing this game! it isnt like dark souls... if you cant land on eelooo its okay! you can land on the mun! or duna! and this is just sandbox! on career its the same except you have objectives so it is even more fun! just dont ragequit! the devs are makin so much content its ridiculous! they are even thinking about making randomely generated solar systems!  this game is my favouurite game in the universe! (literrally) i didnt even think i would enjoy it as im not even into building/science/simulator games but this was entirely unexpected! its so good! if you dont believe me, download the trial then buy the game! - Launched my first unmanned satellite to the orbit, then I realized that I forgot to put batteries and solar panels. - Launched my first manned space ship to the orbit, then I realized that I forgot to put parachutes while landing on the surface. - Launched my first space ship with lander to the moon, then I realized that I forgot to put landing gears. - Launched my second space ship with lander to the moon with landing gears, then I realized that I forgot to put illuminators while landing on the dark side of moon. - Launched my third space ship with lander to the moon with landing gears and illuminators, then I realized that I forgot to put more fuel tanks to land on the surface successfully. - Launched my first manned orbital science lab to the orbit, then I realized that I forgot to put enough batteries and solar panels again. - Launched my first unmanned one-way satellite to the Duna, then I realized that I forgot to put communication devices. - Launched my first manned space ship to the Eeloo successfully, then I realized that I forgot to attend my class.   Space exploration is really difficult work to accomplish, and even more and more difficult in real life. If you enjoyed this game, please pay respect to every space scientists and engineers around the world, paving road to the better future of mankind.  P.S.: The game is solid 9/10 stuff for me.
update: 350 hours in, full release behind us and squad is still working on new features. Plus with mods you can play the game forever

If you're interested in rocketry, spaceflight, and learning about how orbital mechanics work, Kerbal Space Program is for you. You'll get to play around with building rockets and learn about the physics of getting everything into orbit. And then you'll learn about the challenges of getting everything back down to the space center. You'll feel a little bad when your adorable little Kerbals get stranded in orbit because you didn't bring enough fuel, and then feel like a hero when you launch a successful rescue mission to bring them home again.

'We do these things because they are hard!'-JFK (Jebediah F. Kerman)  A game that developed with it's community, and has come out nearly perfect as a released product, as a result. While future developments will continue to improve this game, there's no doubt that it is, and has always been, worth the price. See you in space!  The “Just 5 More Minutes” Award This award is for the game that keeps you playing late.
10/10 best space ship sim to use, teaches you about space more than your science teacher would. FUN, BUY WHEN ON SALE

Great game, my favorite game in the world. So much to do, so little time! Space exploration is Kerbal Space Program. Build a ship, send it out to the mun or further, try to land and take a surface sample. Great early access game, can't wait to see the final build.  Edit: After several years of being addicted to KSP. I still have nothing to say bad about KSP. One of the few games that took advantage of the Early Access program and has delivered everything that was promised. 1.0 is a completed game that fixed many of the bugs that were in early access. The game is better than ever and the team behind the game has continued to show support for future developments to come. I HIGHLY SUGGES KSP to anybody who is up for a challenge and enjoys sandbox/simulation style gameplay. And I can't wait for multiplayer!

One of the best games to simply have fun in. Innumerable hours can be spent creating and crashing vehicles. Also one of the most satisfying games… from your first circular orbit to landing on another planet.

Kerbal Space Program leaves everything to you. You have to finance your space agency, manage it, keep it up-to-date, and create spacecrafts and spaceplanes. KSP allows a wide variety of challenges, including landing on other planets. KSP is certainly not easy to master. However, if you can study extensively, you have what it takes to creat a space agency dominating NASA and the ESA in terms of accomplishments. KSP will keep you in its grasp for hours, conquering space. How hard can rocket science be, anyways?

This is a great game for creative people who don't mind somewhat of a challenge. This game inspired me to build a space station and send a base to Mun (THE MOON)! Things I thought would never interest me but have now become part of my gaming experience.

This game is worth every bit of money spent. It is amazing and funny when you see your ship explode (given that's not the point of the game, it's just I fail a lot). Easily the best spaceflight simulator I've ever played. And though it could certainly help to have a good grasp of physics and mathematics, it's not a requirement for playing this game. And if you so desire, you can play around with the numerous mods offered by the community for added depth and features. The community is friendly, helpful, and passionate about the game, and the developers have done a tremendous job with it. A 10/10 experience, worth your time and effort.

Do not let the number of hours I have playing KSP on Steam fool you. I have done over 1000 hours playing KSP with mods. That cannot be achieved with the stock game on steam.  Ok, so, do I recommend this game? Yes and No. Do I love this game? I DO!  At first glance, anyone that does not know much about it, look at the funny videos of kerbals (those little green guys) and some nice pics of space stations and so on, and think: 'another stupid kids game'. That could not be farther from the true.  Be aware that I play this game since alpha, and many bad critics here are old and while the game was in develop.  This is a hard game to master, its fun, its frustrating, its amazing rewarding when you achieve some hard contract or when you set up your own goals.  Forget space has you know it! No aliens, no space combat, no warpdrives (mods ;) ) nothing like that. This is a pure space game with physics (almost real) with real physics solar system.  You will learn how to fly a rocket or a space plane, get it into orbit, make a transfer to the moon (mun in kerbal language) land (read crash) and visit other far away planets. While doing this, you must take into account, fuel, weight, for each stage while you launch your rocket into the air until it reaches space.  Play sandbox mod and do your thing, or play in career mode and go from there.   So if my critic is all about saying good of KSP why did I say that I do recommend it and not? Well, if you do not have the feeling for space in a newton manner, if you do not grasp at least how things behave in space or, in this case, how to fly something in space, if you do not know anything from physics with low G and the notion of gravity, then go play something else.   KSP is all about the chanllange of building something and trying to achieve something. There are many terms people use in game, this from the Astronomy, engineering and so on. So, in fact, you do not need to be a rocket scientist, but it helps! :P  The community is amazing, I never saw so many people dedicated to one game like KSP. NASA even toke notice of KSP and decided to sponsor the game for education pourposes.   KSP is on of those true gems that I am glad I own and love it. In KSP the challange is you and your goals, and the more you know about KSP, the more you understand it, the more challenging it will become just because you always want more and do more complex and difficult things.  Add mods to the game and be prepared for some really true amazing experiences in space. The community has a huge selection of mods that are constantly updated to make the game more silly or more real, you choose. Me? I prefer the cold hard reallity of space, where your life, in this the Kerbals lives, are in your hands. From mods that give you life support, mining, radiation and heat problems in space or caused by friction, you have mods for everything.  This is one of the most fun games I have played in about....10 years. And I do play some great games not all in steam. I love space games, from Elite, to the X series, Eve online and even startrek online. This had nothing to do with all those games. This is a 99% pure space simulator where you are the boss. Well, you do run a space program you know? Try to do better them NASA ;)  If you like me, do buy this game.
The main thing that will keep you playing this game is the urge to figure out what makes your ships fly well and what makes them crash into the ground as a large fireball.

On the surface, KSP may look like a simple game about building, launching and crashing rockets, but by the time that you've managed to get something to land on Eeloo, you're probably fully qualified to work at NASA.  On a more serious note, this is an all round great game, for people who want to make explosions and people who want to engage in dangerous missions to distant planets alike. The art style itself is cartoonish, whilst maintaining a fair amount of realism. The UI is also very well designed.  Gameplay is fun, whether it's building a 200 part asparagus staged rocket, flying a bizarre ion powered SSTO or trying to get Jeb to the Mun using only an EVA suit. With the randomness of the game, even a routine mission to low orbit can be a disaster, keeping the game ftom getting repetitive.  My only complaints are going to have to be the chosen engine, which I can hardly complain about because a good Unity game will take full advantage of it.  I'd recommend this game to anyone who likes building things to destroy them, building things only to watch them destroy themselves, and building things which miraculously work.
Learnt more about Astrophysics and Rocketry in this game than my whole life. And if you are wondering if you should buy it, just go for it. You will not regret it.

KSP is one of those games where you either love it or can't get into it at all. There are a lot of reviews on this game, some say how it's super difficult... and others say how rewarding and challenging it is. That's what most of them sound like, but what I'm going to do is review the kind of person that loves KSP. Kindof like a psychological evaluation.  For each question, answer 1-5 with 1 meaning 'this doesn't sound like me at all' and 5 meaning 'this is all me all the time'. 1) I enjoy 'fiddling' with something until it works 2) I science all the things. 3) I enjoy building contraptions. 4) I like big explosions and going *really* fast. 5) I enjoy a challenge. 6) I like simulation/management games where decisions involve risk/reward tradeoffs. 7) I prefer sandbox style of play.  If you score anything over a 20, or if you're still curious anyway (worth at least 20 points by itself) read on. This game is fantastic just plain vanilla.  ***however*** The mods and community make it infinitely better. If you take a look through the mods on the KSP forum, you'll find something you enjoy. Also, CKAN (comprehensive kerbal archive network) is a tool you can download that will find, list, and manage your mods for you. It's easy to use.  Types of mods depending on the game *you* want to play: -Just like building and flying but hate mathing? Use Kerbal Engineer Redux and read up on dV requirements. -Rather build ships and manage your space empire without worrying about piloting? Use MechJeb. -Want to manage colonies? Use MKS/OKS for all your kolonization. -Want to make it more difficult? This list is endless... life support mods, mods that add random malfunctions, mods that increase the scale of the world, etc -Want to shoot stuff from your shiny new plane or orbital bombardment satellite? Lost of weapons mods are available. -Want to reenact old missions? There are recreation mods and 'stockalike' mods galore, also remote-tech mod. -Want to build crazy contraptions? Use infernal robotics.

This bloody game! Its a game you can leave and come back to for a few days. It's entertaining and in so many ways nicely challenging.  Bad bits; *Occasional crashes, not that launching the game is a problem. *Demanding. I'm not building a 1000 piece ship, but knock your space station and you'll notice the effects. Would be interesting to see if this game could use Mantle or something to ease system stress. *Remake factor. I cant see Kerbal 2, or how this could work. Space is sadly in infancy as far as real life is concerned. This game covers everything we as humans have done, in fiction anyway. Making it Sci-Fi wouldn't work.  Good bits; *Everything. Variety, the game modes, the visuals, the sense of achievement. You'll land on Mun (the nearest moon) and feel as tall as a giant. You'll then slowly after much experimentation send people to other moons and planets. Each mission really making you punch the air and shout 'YES' with happiness.  Long term bits; *I'm starting to run out of planets, I have sent jets to land on planets to save failed missions. The science lab is becoming a pain as Science is maxed out once you have a few working around your system. The games feeling complete. This is sad but the 200hrs have been emotional and blissful.  The game is in a class of its own and is a great. Recommended? Definitely YES!

If you've ever wanted to go to space, land on the moon, build your own rocket, space plane or rover, or if you have an AI core in your head that just won't shut up about Space, then this is the game for you!  Its set in the Fictional Kerbol solar System, similar to ours with an Earth, Moon, Jupiter, Pluto, Mars and Venus analogue, but about 1/3 the size of everything (so orbit is way easier to achieve).  Kerbin has the same gravity as Earth, and despite the cartoonish green heads and stupid grins on the faces of the Kerbals, (and unusually high survivability), you actually launch (nearly) realistic NASA style missions, with some simplified physics thrown in.  There is something of a learning curve (it IS rocket science after all), but lots of tutorials can get you to space, orbit, the Mun and beyond, and with no Maths required! (technically). You may even end up accidentally learning in depth about Dealta V and orbital mechanics, and while you CAN perfectly design missions to be efficient and elegent, brute forcing your way through with more boosters, fuel and struts is always an option.  Your successes will actually feel like a huge achievement (landing on the Mun for the first time for one), and all your failures will (usually) be peppered with huge explosions, so even failure feels surprisingly fun.  New parts and systems keep being added to this game even now, and there are a huge variety of mods for those that want new parts, more challenge, or some aids to help along the way (Kerbel Engineer really feels like it should be a stock part of the game).  Kerbal Space Program: Because there won't be any little green men on Duna (Mars) unless you get them there first.

This game is fantastic. Honestly. It may just be the nerd in me, but I have so much fun playing this game! For those who are unaware, Kerbal Space Program is basically a game that uses realistic physics in an ingame solar system. There really is no goal for the player, save maybe to get to other planets. The player has at their disposal, many different rocket parts, as well as plane parts (for those aero enthusiasts such as I) to do, well whatever they want. There are three different game modes, Career, Science (!), and Sandbox. Career mode places the player in control of the Kerbal Space Center (or KSC) and your goal is to complete contracts and get to other planets. You have to balance your budget, while at the same time getting enough science to unlock new parts. Your buildings also have limitations, such as the launch pad only being able to launch rockets that are say 15 tons. As you progress, it is necessary to upgrade these building to bigger and way more awesome vehicles. In Science (!) mode, you begin with every building at the highest level, and without the worries of balanceing your budget (fancy way for saying there is no money), and your only goal is to launch missions and get science to unlock more parts. Finally there is sandbox mode. For those gamers out there unfamiliar with the term, sandbox is generally used to refer to a gamemode in which everything is unlocked, and you may run wild. That said, in this gamemode, you may run wild. There is no goal whatsoever and you have everything in the game. I play the game while running mac OS X El Capitan (for those who don't know their OS, on apple computers, click the apple on the top left of your screen and click 'about this mac' and it will tell you) the game is very well polished and I haven't run into any atrocious glitches yet. I highly recommend this game and I hope that if you get it you have great fun. Happy gaming,  Mackels. (UPDATE) Even after copius hours spent playing this game, it still fails to bore, I support fully everything I have said previously.

[Review for the Steam Awards 2016]  Very fun space/flight/crashing simulation game, large selection of mods, tools, visual enhancements and possibilities.  Teaches aerophysics and orbital mechanics in a simple illustrative way. Showing how applying thrust in the X, Y and Z axis changes the shape and angle of an orbit.  How the Oberth effect works on spacecraft using gravitational assistance from Planets/Moons to save fuel, along with the importance of center of mass, thrust to weight ratio, and the aerodynamics of aircraft/spacecraft (rockets).  The learning curve can be steep, but once you start to understand it and achieve things inside the game, the payoff feels amazing.

Nominated for the “Whoooaaaaaaa, dude!” Award 2016  This is a game that incorporates all the hard science of a true spacecraft simulator (like Orbiter) without any of the precision necessary to launch a real spacecraft into whatever rock orbits the Sun. The planets in KSP's solar system are smaller and have less atmosphere than our real solar system and so, KSP is easy to get into and it's easy to break out of our home planet's atmosphere, but it's very very hard to master and you will find yourself seeping in all the youtube tutorials before you make anything cooler than a crater on the ground.   There's a creative mode where you have all the parts and no restrictions, perfect to go wild. There's also a career mode, but makes the game even harder, because you start with very little pieces and you can make very few missions at a time and you have to focus your efforts into completing those missions, acquiring science to unlock parts and upgrading the buildings. But, it does feel like you're actually starting something like the Project Mercury and going to Apollo and beyond. Recommended if you wanna learn about realistic orbital navigation, especially if you are already a fan of true space simulators
A nice past time when you have work to do, why do science in real life when you can do it in a game!

Where to even begin? Writing a review for this game is a bit like writing a review for 'Human Being'. Anything from 'what the hell is this', to 's'alright' to 'ho-lee-fook what is this' would all be perfectly udnerstandable responses to this game (I'll let my play time clue you in on where I stand).  First, I'll clear the air a bit and let you know that if you're troublehooting game is weak, probably best to call in sick because to get this game purring and shooting for the stars will require a fair bit of research. But oh hell does it pay off. THat first landing on the Mun will make you feel like Neil frickin' armstrong. On to greater thigns and landing on analogues of mars, even neptune.  But then, after months of perfecting your a-game you stumble across mods. These delightful little additions (ranging from several Kb to half a gig) will do anything from turning your rockets into burgers through to deliviring the real feel of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ space program, failures an' all.  I'd like to give a special shout out to that last one, having played for several years now I have ascended to true masochism and installed a plethora of modlets called 'realism overhaul' and 'realistic-progression zero'. Starting with the basic parts of a post- WWII V2 rocket your task is quite literally to emulate NASA. And by that I mean I now understand actual rocket science. To some extent at least.  I cannot recommend this game enough. Seriosuly, the difficulty is entirely down to how you play, the payoffs are indescribable and the amount you'' start reading just to get that sodding first man on the moon will spark passion in the hearts of seasoned star gazers and pre-binocular stage foot-studiers alike.  It's buggy as all hell on low end machines, and as unoptimised as the New US president Elects hair shader model. But god damn if it a'int fun!

Here we have a fun little-big sandbox of the physics variety. The concept is simple, but the magnitude of options are incredibly detailed. You must explore the Kerbol System and its collection of planetary bodies, asteroids and satellites with machines you build at your hub/base on the tiny world of Kerbin. Strapping adventurous little Kerbals into your haphazardly cobbled, and most certainly dangerous, rockets and aircraft you aim them towards the heavens and thus towards glory. Why you ask? For Science! That delicious, delicious science.  From this title I learned some of the intricacies of orbital mechanics, the methods of calculating delta-v, and the anguish (or pride) of blasting little green people into the depths of interstellar space ... never to return. When played in CAreer Mode I must say, 'Buyer beware!' This is a game not for the feint of heart nor those who are easily frustrated by extremely repetitious failure. Laugh, learn and launch towards the howling abyss that is Space!   To quote aptly, 'Fly Safe' ...

The short - if you ever wanted to peek behind the curtain of spaceflight, build insane things that go boom or stick you flag in soil untouched by man or kerbal this is the game for you. KSP leaves the “what and how” of rockets to you, it will suggest things to accomplish but ultimately it is up to you to pick the challenge that you want to overcome.   I have spent far too much time playing KSP, and I’ve realized it’s an odd game. It combines several different games into one sandbox: rocket and plane builder, flight simulator, and space sim. Basically it all boils down to being a NASA simulator as you have to take on all the roles of NASA from astronaut, to engineer, to mission planner and deal with most of the challenges that come with those jobs. Therfore it has a steep learning curve, weight to trust ratios, orbital maneuvers, rendezvous and docking, aero-breaking, and dreaded geo-breaking aka crash landings. But don’t get too intimidated the community loves to help new players learn the basics of space travel and they will walk you through the 101 of, rockets, planes, and whatever else you might need help with.   How ambitious you are drives the difficulty of the game, whether you’re happy just flying by the Mun or do want to land on it or are you sights set on more distant worlds, do plan to bring your crew back or find one way trips to be best budget friendly solution. In KSP don’t be afraid to fail it’s part of the fun, watching a rocket spin out of control and explode, I’ve dragged the broken remains of many a crashed rocket back to Kerbal on their last engines. If something does go wrong and your kerbonauts are stranded, will there be rescue mission? It’s all up to you, the where, how, and will they ever see Kerbal again or will home just be a twinkle in an alien sky.

I love KSP. Simply one of the best flight/space sims out there. Elite: Dangerous is amazing too, but generally very serious, whereas Kerbal Space Program is fun to mess around with. Adding mods to spice up the already stunning gameplay is easy, with the developers making it as easy as dragging one folder into another. The controls are easy to use, but hard to master, and you will almost always explode on your first try of making a successful rocket. But who cares? Just sit back and watch the fireworks. KSP has plenty of planets and moons to visit, all of which provided their own challenge and hidden easter eggs (all of which tend to be very amusing). One thing to beware of is the Kraken. He will destroy your ships and send Bill Kerman flying off on an unintended trajectory if provoked. They say the Kraken was killed/patched and is gone forever. Being completely honest, I think he still lurks out near Jool, perhaps even on one of it's moons....  All in all, amazing game full of explosions and fun. Ten outta ten.

KSP is, without a doubt, the best early-access game out right now.  Reasons why:  • Constantly being updated  • One of the best modding communities out there  • Only 30 dollars  • An entire solar system filled with Planets and Moons to explore  • Even if this game somehow gets abandoned by the developers, it still has enough content to justify it.(unlike most early access games)  • You can use your own imagination to create the vehicles you want.  • Even thought it has 'Space Program' in the name, it's not only locked to space crafts. You can build cars, planes, boats, helicopters, etc.  • (For the most part) Realistic physics.  • Full sized planets.  • Career mode.  • Sandbox mode.  • You can transport asteroids...  The only cons I could think of:  • No variety in Kerbal appearances, unless you use mods.  • Physics become glitchy when you speed up time.  This game is definately worth the 30 dollars, and is better than most games today, especially early-access games.

I love this game but it sucks.  That's how my review started almost exactly one year ago. A year later I think that it still holds true. The game is addictive and fun but still very obviously an indie title, though now on version 1.1 it has addressed some of the issues I originally had.   First off the game has updated it's interface to look more modern as well as added new funtionality such as the much needed KSPedia that outlines all of the parts and buildings in the game. They also added much better biginner tutorials and some great scenarios you can jump right into to test yourself and hone your skills.  However there are still a lot of bugs in the game, such as the wonky physics that will often have your ships jiggle and explode for no obvios reason. For serious players this can be very annoying but I guess it does add to the 'Kerbalness' of the game.  Overall I still love this game and now feel better about recommending it to players who may have been on the fence about purchasing it.  To see my original review keep reading.  Original Review from May 14 2015  Let me clarify. I have been playing Kerbal Space Program since version 0.23 and I have been loving every minute of it and if you look at my profile you will see that that's a lot of minutes but what was so much fun in alpha and beta does not make this a finished game. If you are beginner you will most likely get very frustrated, very fast. The tutorials are basic and do not teach you the skills needed to play the game. Once you learn some of the basics it is better and I would recommend watching you tube let's plays and in particular Scott Mannly has a great set of KSP 101 videos. Once you have done that then you will enjoy this game much more but be careful, KSP can be a huge time sink as you try just one more mission or you keep going to unlock just one more tech.  Having followed the dev team for years I was hoping for so much more from a 1.0 release but this really isn't much more than what was in the beta. The game is still great once you master the basics but it just doesn't do a good job teaching those basics or easing the player into the game. It's just here is your space center now go! I would have liked some videos or step by step beginner missions that would walk the player through building a ship, collecting science and upgrading your first building.  Get the demo, watch some you tube lets plays and then buy the game once you're comfortable.  I love this game and I can't wait to see what else Squad does to improve it (better graphics would be nice, it's very 2002) but with the incredibly high learning curve I can't recommend this game to first time players.

I bought this game before there was a career mode, and even then it was worth the money.  There really is no other game out on the market quite like this, and if your fascinated with space and rockets, then you will definitely want this game. Some people consider the learning curve to be really steep, and it is, but its done in a intuitive way that will allow you to progress by trial and error if need be.  While there are not many tutorials, there are a handful that will teach you the basics and some of the advanced techniques used to explore the kerbal solar system.  Playing the science mode is great for learning all the parts and how to start with barely any technology.  Sandbox is awesome for just messing around and practicing techniques you learned in the tutorial, or building the rocket or space plane of your dreams.  Career mode is my favorite, while the contracts can be repetitive sometimes, and it feels like a grind for money, it still feels great to accomplish missions like building a base on the moon or another planet with nothing but a few parts, some brave kerbals, and a little bit of cash. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who liked legos as a kid, or is fascinated by space.

Between the crashes and a couple elements of the tutorial being broken I wouldn't say it quite merits the 1.0, but everything else is pretty impressive and fun. Unleash your inner pyromaniac in the designing of shuttles, then try to actually explore a fictional solar system resembling our own by putting them to practical use. It's the closest thing to a good edutainment game I've seen since the 90's, and although it's rather a boiled-down approach for the everyman to be able to understand it still presents a good deal of complexity and challenge.  Would be nice if it'd stop crashing, though. Been waiting, like, two years for that.

Ever wished you could blow up expensive rockets in an attempt to fly into outer space? Ever dreamed of creating a vast empire of space ships for no reason? Ever wanted to control a squadron of green men? Ever thought that Jeb is a real badass? If you answered yes to any of these questions then you are wasting your time reading this and should already be buying Kerbal Space Program. But for those of you still reading and need further reason to play this game then I'll tell you about my experiences thus far. When starting KSP you run around a bit like a child in a sweet shop. There is so many possibilities waiting for you to explore and you don't really know where to begin. However, after exploring the tutorials further you begin to realize how amazing this game is and know where you need to start. With the options of career or sandbox mode, KSP provides something for any gamer. There is endless fun waiting for you. Whether you are recreating the space race of the 60's or creating weird and wonderful jet fighters and space stations, you will always have something bigger and even more spectacular that you will create.

The day has come. KSP 1.0 is finally out. Big thanks to Squad for their commitment to the project. The game is trully perfect and infinite fun. Moreover, KSP has THE friendliest community. Even minimal involvement will make your KSP experience richer. Thank you, thank you, thank you. Teams like Squad (although they are trully unique) give me faith in the gaming industry.

If you dont already have this game, GET IT NOW. It is mindlessly fun especially when you have no idea what you are doing, and there is nothing more satisfying than successfully landing on the Mun for the first time let alone another planet. I got this game way before it was available on Steam and played it for hours on end, in total I have probably played it for around 200 hours and I still find enjoyment in it. It is well worth the price of $27(in the US) with all the features implemented now and in the future along with the available mods to make your experience playing even more enjoyable.  UPDATE  Kerbal Space Program has now officially launched out of Early Access and at the time of this review is $30.00 with a normal price of $40.00. Now if this turns you away from the game I have two things to say to you. One why didnt you get it when it was in Early Access was $27.00(or less) and worth so much more. And two the $40.00 price tag still is much lower than the game is actually worth, a game like this if made by a large company like Ubisoft or Rockstar would be priced at upwards of $60.00. The game is a masterpiece and so fun, with hours of gameplay available, the learning curve while steep at first levels out until you can get a ship into orbit paying little attention to the game. So to sum up everything I've said and won't say(to keep this review semi-short), BUY THIS GAME NOW, DON'T THINK ABOUT IT JUST PUT IT INTO YOUR CART AND BUY IT!!!!

Fantastic!  Kerbal is, more than anything else, an eductaional course in stellar physics and the properties of atmospheric flight, orbital flight and space exploration. It is rich, deep and surprisingly realstic. This offers a rather challenging gameplay at first, as reaching the Mun requires understanding the basics of space flight, such concepts as Delta-V changes, apo- and periapsial alterations and of course, the complex attempt to balance between thrust, mass and fuel.   It's awesome. It's one of the finest simulations I've seen in my life.
