Kerbal Space Program is finally at it's full release, but is it any good? At it's core Kerbal Space Program is a rocket-building simulator. You strap together stacks of assorted pieces like rocket fuel, engines and crew capsules, then blast off see how far you can go! The game is a lot of fun, there is no doubt about it. It has all the tools needed to appeal to a casual observer, and with the right mods it can appeal to even some of the more hardcore enthusiasts. It has my highest recommendation.  If you need to know more, if you are on the fence, there was a video made for the game several years ago which best captures the spirit and intent of KSP. Beyond it's veneer of silly green men and the often odd sense of humor is a dream of reaching out to the stars. To that end, the Build. Fly. Dream. trailer is the best depiction of why you should play this game.          YouTube™ Video:  KSP Build Fly Dream Trailer

Rooted in our deep longing for the knowledge of the unknown and fueled by the passion shared by the nations for exploration of the cosmos many years before, Kerbal space program is a rare genre of game, one that asks you not only of your skill and wit, but of your patience and ingenuity. It's the kind of game that is filled with daunting goals and impossible odds, and despite your failures, the game's clever design and lighthearted tone won't ever get you down or tell you to give up.  Through trials and tribulations you push harder, work smarter and get ever closer to your destination until finally, you make it, punctuating the monotony and giving the rare and satisfying moments of pure triumph. A game where you can revel in your victory and tell yourself, with utter certainty, that 'I did it. It really worked.'

Best game I have ever played.  At first, I couldn't even get 10,000 Meters, or 10 KM in the sky. My rockets always exploded. But I learned, Built more complex staging arrays, and eventually got into orbit. I knew I was half way to the Mun.  I discovered how useful SRBs were (I used the Kickback Ones). Then I used the Mammoth Liquid fuel engine, and I set off for the Mun.  After I landed on the Mun, I landed on Minmus. Then I continued into the Solar System and landed on Duna.  In my opinion, Duna is the easiest planet to land on. The atmosphere's reentry does almost nothing to you, and Parachutes work on Duna.  However, in recent days, I could no longer load saved games.  10/10   And now, for the silly part.  First time playing: 'OMG Y IS MEH ROCKET EXPLODING WHY IS THERE FIRE'  400th Hour Playing: 'If I am correct, I will need 1700 m/s of Delta-V to reach Duna with the supplies in order for my colony of 32 kerbals to live.'

HEAD FOR PLUTO, LAND ON AN ASTEROID, HELL BRING AN ASTEROID BACK TO YOUR HOME PLANET!! THAT'S WHAT KERBAL SPACE PROGRAM IS!!! Just expect to lose about 437 men and women in the progress of learning, 736 astronauts in the designing of your rocket ship and 1757 astronauts in the launching of the actual thing.   The thing about this game is that it has a steep learning curve due to the many concepts they use such as manipulating orbits to slingshot yourself off to the Mun (that's not a typo mind you), making proper alignments of centers of mass, centers of lift and centers of thrust, effects of atmosphere and aerodynamics as well. It's fun to see your rocket designs crash, explode and implode with little green astronauts I have to admit, but nothing's more satisfying than seeing one safely land home.

This game is awesome BUT it has a few issues, I will list them and the good stuff.  GOOD Scenarios: there are 6 scenarios that can be completed with skill and sometimes luck.  Tutorials: although there are not many, the tutorials provide valuable information that you can use on your interplanetary voyage.  Ship Building: The ship building system is awesome and can be mastered in 5-10 minutes So many parts: this game has 227+ 'vanilla' parts right now and more on the way. Symmetry: Cuts the ship building time in half or even more Easy move keys: using basic key bindings you can move a ship part into just the right position.  Spaceplanes: using basically the same system as the ship building, the spaceplane hangar is a good ally, and if fun to use.  Asteroids: This game allows you to capture asteroids and do whatever you want with them  Planets: This game has 7 (really 6) 'vanilla' planets and 9 moons to explore and build bases on.  MODS: This game is modable, but it's mods are not on steam but instead on KSP mod sites like  kerbalstuff.com  and the kerbal spaceport  Easy modding: you can learn the code for this game with relative ease, the textures and 3D models can also be customized for the right look for your new part.  BAD Buggy: Usually buggy when you start making large crafts. (Unity) Control Fails: Although uncommon they do happen and may cause your ship to explode. The Kraken: An annoying bug that can cause many things to happen, in 1.0 it's rarer  SUMMARY If what you read makes you not want to buy this game, BUY IT, IT IS FREAKING AWESOMELY EPIC! (I am still working on this review)

First Mun fly-by, halfway there, when... 'Houston, we have a problem.' 'What's the problem?' 'Forgot to bring the parachute!'  Rescued astronaut stranded in orbit. 'We are going home.' Lined up my descent burn. 'Fire engines.' All is well. Screen suddenly fills up. Slammed into stranded astronaut's derelict spaceship. Boom. Some rescue.  Best game ever. 10/10.

I run the game from the exe rather than through steam so my hours on record are completely out. I estimate I have spent about 60 - 80 hours on it in the last month. There are some frustrating elements to this game in career mode such as docking. Loads of precision needed but all in all good fun.  So what can you do.  Build a rocket Get into space Get into orbit Visit a moon Break Kerbin's (the Kerbals home planet) orbit Visit other planets  Ok so thats the basics  Rockets are only half the story. What sort of craft can you make  Rockets Landers Probes Fuelling rockets Rovers Planes Space planes Very expensive fireworks Orbital stations  The game gets hard hard when you reach the stage that you want to leave Kerbin's orbit and go to another planet. Its all about efficiency and timing. (There is a cheat menu if you get stuck or need to skip a stage).  Unlike our planet, Kerbin has 2 moons. The moon further out called Minmus is much easier to land on if you are struggling with landing and returning. I still have not successfully landed on the Mun AND returned.  Buy this game while its on sale!!!

First off, I want to make it clear that I really enjoy the game, and I'm a huge fan. Absolutely incredible. If you're even considering buying it, just do it. There's always more to do, and it's always a challenge. There's a multitude of mods, and there's always something to do. However, I can't say I'm a fan of the new update, 1.0.5. I like the new features and all, but now it's been bogged down. I originally had a whole ton of mods such as visual enhancements, EVA enhancements, engine lighting, outer planets, and all that stuff running at 60 fps. As soon as I got the update, I was down to 15-20. After uninstalling all the mods 'n stuff, I was only gettiing mid 40's. I don't know what happened between 1.0.4 and 1.05, but it did drag down my game quite a bit. I still recommend the game though, as a high frame rate isnt exactly a necessity to the gameplay.

An excellent, fun, creative, funny, and engaging game that puts you in the position of a ruthless engineer who will sacrifice Kerbals just for fun in the Sandbox mode or for more resources in the Career mode.

Not a game for everyone, but this game is unique in my experience at providing a 'thinking game' where precision, planing and a rudimentary understanding of physics and orbital mechanics are rewarded, whilst still providing humour, fun, and the odd cataclysmic explosion and firey death to your poor Kerbal astronaut.  It should be said that you do not need to be a rocket scientist to play this game, or even to play it well. If you don't send rockets inot space for a living, to enjoy this game immensley you simply need to be able to see the funny side of said explosions and get over a failed mission that might have taken rather a lot of concentration, planing and effort. Then try again. Know that the genuine feeling of reward you get for landing safely on a distant planet makes it all seem worth it.  The game has a number of tutorial scenarios that are well worth getting through if you want to hit the ground running - of course youtube also has some great tutorials. Not sure if the moderators allow a plug here, but Scott Manley is particularly good (and funny!). Perhaps it will be allowed given I have no affiliation or stand to gain in any way. But honestly I'd have crashed a lot more without his videos!!  Happy spacefaring!

'One small step for Kerbal...' *static* 'One giant leap for Kerbalkind...'  Nothing can describe the feelings of accomplishment and joy when I first set Kerbal boots onto the surface of the Mun. There was no in-game achievement pop up. But that's what made it that much more enjoyable. Ever since I did my first fly-by I knew my next goal would be to land there. And after many unsuccessful attempts I finally touched down on the surface.  My next problem faced me immediately. I didn't have enough fuel for the return trip.  And THAT is what makes this game so amazing. The challenge lies in planning ahead. Overcoming obstacles you might not have thought of initially. I ended up building a fuel tanker and launching that into a Mun orbit where I was able to successfully dock and transfer fuel.  At the same time it's fun to just build something ridiculous and to see what happens. It's just as enjoyable when it ends in an explosion.  As a newbie I started off on the career mode. Sandbox was too intimidating. Too many parts, no idea what they do. Career gives you basic parts and you have to unlock the rest. So you have a lot more understand of what parts you want to unlock and what they do.  I give this game a solid 10. If you enjoy setting challenges yourself and don't mind failing occasionally then you'll love it. It's a whole lot of fun and I've barely scratched the surface yet!

This is a game that is really expansive in the ways it allows you to play with its complex and near-realistic physics engine. Do you want to build a giant phallis and thrust it into orbit? The game allows you to do that. Do you want to simulate running an actual space program, complete with research, funds, and logistical factors? The game supports that too. Of all the simulators out there, Kerbal Space Program is one of the absolute best.  Keep in mind there will be a steep learning curve, so don't be afraid to view plenty of tutorials and helpers.
Beware. You will get lost in this game in the same way you lost Jebediah in orbit. Your wife will have to send a rescue mission for you. A+ would learn orbital mechanics again.

So, in my early access review I complained a lot about how the 'Career Mode' was incredibly tedious for this kind of game. Since then, the game has had some serious updates and has been officially released. Emphasis on 'serious'. I don't know if I hadn't played it for long enough, or if they had updated a few things, but for me it now has that anyone-can-do-it feel back. But enough of me referencing a review that is now gone, let me give you my final review for this game:  Kerbal Space Program is an RTS space sandbox/space program simulator set in another world far away from ours, yet similar in many ways. You play as a race of cute little green men called 'Kerbals' (hence the name) that are in charge of a space program. It is your one and only true goal to manage this space program and to make it the best of the best. This requires researching new tech, building complex spacecraft, and choosing from an assortment of camaigns/strategies to increase your income in a specific field.  There are three main things that you must manage: reputation, money, and science. Your reputation determines how willingly people sign up to be a part of your program and how willingly people will offer you contracts. Your money is what you use to purchase parts and to upgrade different facilities. Finally, science is used to research the parts you will need to get to space and beyond. Another thing to note is that there are ores. As of now I do not have that much experience, and I have yet to see them. However, I assume they are used to buid things on the go and provide extra fuel for your long space journeys (the ladder I know is true).  This, however, is only true if you play career mode. There are a few other modes along with a custom one, where you can edit different options like money earned and cost of parts, to choose from. As I said earlier, there is a sandbox mode where you don't have to worry about money or reputation or science and you can build what you like. In this mode all facilities are upgraded to the max and all parts are already researched for you. This is if you just want to mess around with designs, or want to play without limitations. For those who like the idea of earning points to research parts but aren't a big fan of money and reputation holding them back, there is science mode. Science mode is similar to career mode, but without money and reputation. Think of it as a toned-down version of career mode. There is still something to work towards, but nothing is stopping you if you want to make a giant cruise missile out of some solid fuel boosters.  I could go on for paragraphs, but I think you get the point of the game.  TLDR Mark:  Pros: Excellent progression system Great graphics (for a game of this scale) Astonishing physics and aerodynamics Amazing soundtrack Great modding support and community Good for all Kinds of players One of the few Early Access games that made it out of Early Access  Cons: Can get tedious at times Time consuming Incredibly HARD and UNFORGIVING learning curve  Final Verdict: Kerbal space program is a great space exploration game that teaches people the lifelong lesson of why we use the phrase 'It's not rocket science'. Great for casuals, try-hards, and noobs alike. Overall I give it a 9/10. Nothing's better than the first time you get to the moon and realize you don't have enough fuel to get back.

Ah Kerbal Space Program.... Where do I start. I saw this game a couple weeks ago when I was at my friend's house. He said it was nearly impossible to get to the Mun. I picked the game up, started Carrear mode, and 5 hours later Jeb landed on the moon with half the delta V of my friend. With ny landing legs. So I sent a rescure rocked up and saved the hero. I then found the mods. OH MY GOD THE MODS. If you like space, get this game. If you like explosions, get this game. If you like little green men and women, get this game. GET THIS GAME.

If you're like many people who wanted to be an astronaut, or fly into space, at some point in your life, this is the game for you. You control a NASA-like space program, where your goal in life is to sent your little green kerbals into space...and hopefully bring some of them back alive(or don't....we have reserves).   What makes the game so great is the fact that you can build pretty much anything you want and shoot your creations into space to see if they actually work. The physics engine is incredibly robust, and like it or not, you will learn about rocket science and orbital mechanics if you spend any time in this game. You might even end up enjoying it. Just remember that failure(often the explosive kind) is just another opportunity to figure out what you did wrong and improve. You will fail, you will fail often and you'll keep coming back because when you do succeed it will feel great. And you'll understand how hard NASA's job really is(because real life doesn't have a Reset button when the rocket flips over and blows up the space center).   However, if you haven't already figured it out, this game can be difficult, mostly because the game doesn't really tell you how to do much. There are a few very basic tutorials but a lot of the game is learned by trial and error and looking for tutorials on youtube or the KSP wiki to help you overcome the cliff-like learning curve.   The game also has a wonderful modding community and it's the only game where I've actually cared about mods. If you play and feel the game is lacking something, chances are there's a mod that addresses your concerns. The downside of this is that there are a few mods(such as MechJeb) that really feel like they should be part of the base game instead of a recommended mod.   In conclusion, this may be the closest the average person will ever get to not only going into space, but being a spacecraft engineer. If either of those appeal to you, pick this up.

I went walking through a park yesterday.  I saw the dogs playing and the people walking. I saw the trees swaying in the wind and the park benches being park benches. The children were throwing frisbees and laughing as they made fun of their fat friends.  There was a dog who ran up to me with his tongue poking out as he panted happily. I looked at the dog. The dog looked at me. I smiled at the dog. The dog smiled at me. I made a funny face to the dog. The dog bit my leg off, and now I spend my days hopping around collecting minerals (they're not rocks) in my backyard.  So I guess the moral to the story is, if I had have spent more time playing Kerbal Space Program and less time walking through the park, I would be one leg better off.

The international media all know it, the early access community knew it all along and now you know it, too: KSP is  - a hell of a lot of fun - entertaining - educating (omg!) - unique - groundbreaking - mod friendly and mod supportive - ... I could probably go on forever, but you get the point by now.  So you are going to launch a rocket. Just this one more little rocket. And then you'll shut down the PC. Really. And then it fails to reach orbit or overshoots its target and you're caught again. I've clocked more hours using my fantasy, imagination and strive for perfection with this game than with any other game I know. You get to build your dream (in career on a budget), shoot it up to space and hope that it is all going to work out some how. Most of the time it doesn't. In any other game, you would stop at some point of time. Here you won't.  Hell, I even catch myself not reloading the umpteenth quicksave in order to restart with my Kerbal, but rather send out an interplanetary rescue mission to get him/her back at all costs!  Shockingly, after some time you are going to become an expert of some sorts concerning the basic function principles of rockets, orbits, planetary satellites and the otherwise highly complex matter of orbital mechanics.   What KSP is not: - pure eye candy - easy to master - a game you will just 'play through' or 'finish' (it is endless) - perfect and polished. It is not by any means bug free, but the devs are working very hard on it (personal impression).  It's a 10/10, nevertheless. Go on, buy it. Play it, leave it alone for a month. You're going to orbit the game again. Promise.

There are just so many things you can do in KSP! For Example:  > Launch a craft that isn't balanced. Once you realize there's no way you can control it, decide that it was a missile test from the start. Call it a success.  > Launch a probe and put it on course for the Mun. The probe doesn't have solar panels. Not to worry, it was actually just an experiment to see how long the batteries would last in deep space. Also a success.  > Launch a Fuel Station into orbit. Decide it isn't perfect.   > Launch a neat SSTO Spaceplane into orbit. Decide it isn't perfect.  > Launch another Fuel Station into orbit. Decide it isn't perfect.   > Launch a another neat SSTO Spaceplane into orbit. Decide it isn't perfect.  > After countless repetitions of the above phases, enjoy having trouble finding the craft you want in low Kerbin Orbit, because there are so many experimental crafts cluttering that space that your homeworld now looks like Saturn.  > Launch a large expeditionary craft which makes the journey to a distant world like Dres or Eeloo, and land a large family of Kerbonauts onto that world, without the necessary fuel to leave. Realize you forgot to tell the crew they weren't coming home. Just don't tell them. They don't need to know.  > Land on Eve. Doscover there's no chance you can leave Eve. Eve is like a psychotically obsessive girlfreind. She will hang onto you forever.  > Launch a cool interplanetary ship. Use the many other forgotten ships already in orbit to refuel it for its trip.  > Run out of fuel when your return craft is almost (but not quite) in the Kerbin atmosphere. The Kerbonaut decides he can see his house from space and jumps. After using his Jetpack fuel to finish the de-orbit, he survives re-entry and impact with the ground, promptly standing up to greet his freinds.

Humanity really lucked out as far as space travel goes. Earth's mass, and the thick atmosphere that protects our planet means that spacecraft need to acheive ~98% thrust to weight ratios in order to go into space. It was this problem that took our best scientists the better part of 30 years to move past. However, achieving spaceflight from Kerbin should only take you about 30 minutes.   All the glory of space, budget optional.

As of writing this, I'm going to tentatively say that KSP is a worthwhile purchase. If nothing else, you'll likely get quite a few hours out of just the early career mode and plenty of scope to muck around if that's your thing. However, really getting a lot out of the game, and particularly career mode, requires one of two things: Either you will have to be willing/able to do some tedious math each time you design a rocket/plane, or you will need to download and install a third party mod to do the calculations for you. The big reason for this is that getting much further than a basic orbit or short-range one-way flights requires careful calculation of delta-V, a function not performed by the basic game as of writing this review. This is, in my opinion, a nasty oversight on the part of the devs; as it is quite important for anything other than a sandbox game, where cost efficiency doesn't matter.  Overall, if you're keen on the idea of actually doing manual algebra to play a game then this should suit you nicely. If you're happy enough to go and get a mod to do the basic calculations for you, this game should suit you too. If like me you're not fussed about either, look elsewhere. This is a good simulator, but not really a casual player's game.

I have been playing Kerbal Space Program(KSP) for quite some time; 785 hours at the time I write this to be exact. I must simply say that the experience is amazing. I would say the game itself is amazing, but that would not be the entire truth. At it's face it is a space agency simulator. You build rockets, launch them, and hope that a rapid unplanned disassembly does not occur. The career mode offers a way to ease yourself into the increasing complexities of interplanetary travel, while providing a pacing challenge by way of gaining science, and funds. Sandbox allows you to explore all the various parts that KSP has to offer, tired of building rockets? Then build a space plane. It is simple, and complex, in all the right places.   Then there is the community, a group of loving amateur rocketeers, kind of. It appears to me to be a group of people who do math for fun. Some are perhaps truly engineers, and are able to provide you with detailed Delta V maps to aid you in the proper engines, and fuel tank sizes, to get the most efficiency possible. Inevitably you will come to a point when you feel like you may have reached a point where you can no longer progress. The community helps here, explaining different staging methods, and the purpose of Spec Impulse.   The Mods, some are quirky, like chatter, which adds jumbled up versions of NASA tapes to your launches to give your missions a feel of communication. To Mechjeb which some feel is essential. The mods add an entire new experience. Want to make the game harder, more complex, more lifelike, or you want to add Warp Drives to the mix? yeah there is a Mod for that. I recommend a few: Mech Jeb, Kerbal Engineer, Remote Tech, Infernal Robotics, Interstellar, and Kerbal Attachment Systems, just to name a few fun ones.   Then there is the Developers. This is a group of incredible Devs that really get their audience. From the creation of lovable Protagonists, the Kerbals, specifically Jebediah, the most badass space explorer in at least one galaxy. Many pieces of the game have a bit of tounge and cheek. They also listen, if something doesn't work they set out to fix it. If something does, they set out to expand it. All while making the game extremely enjoyable.   This game is worth your time if you follow NASA, or Space X.

Played the game on Knuckle Head Mode (ie; learn on own, trial and error) when it was still in beta. First attempt at launching into space in sandbox mode resulted in the rocket slowly falling sideways then exploding before hitting the ground. Laughed reeeeeaally hard for some reason. Then noticed there was a No Regret Button (ie: Return to Launch)  Launch number 20ish(?), I finally was able to get off the ground! I made it to 200 meters while going 8mps... before crashing I hit the Esc button, noticed Jebadiah had a grin from ear to ear, I laughed really hard again realizing that Jeb knew about the No Regret Button. So I let the ship go BOOM and pressed the button after I was done laughing.  Launch 40ish(?) I realize that the rockets I build like doing multiple backflips.......... so yeah.  Launch number 60ish(?) I was able to almost make it to sub orbit. I was happy and so was Jeb. Then realized while the ground was zooming closer, that I forgot to put parachutes on the ship. Jeb enjoyed the ride regardless as it neared the ground and went BOOM.  Launch number 80ish(?) I discover the joys of staging and putting multiple Kerbins in flight on one ship. Go to launch and the rocket explodes. Forgot to stage it properly. The Capsule decides to do multiple backflips. Jeb is loving life. The other Kerbins look like they are about to push out a kidney. Somehow the capsule doesn't explode on impact. All aboard are all smiles, until a piece of the rocket lands next to them exploding the capsule. Laughed so hard that my cheeks, back of my head and stomach hurt from it. Then started farting with each 'HA' that came out my mouth which didn't help the pain go away.   In conclusion, this game gives you gas.  Willing to fart again.

Krbal Space Program is a really, really, really, good game. KSP is a game where you don't have a specific goal: you set your own, and fly off into space with your glorious little Kerbals.  Pros:  1: Lots of stuff to do, either play sandbox, or science mode, or career mode. 2: Play the way you want to play, go where you want, build the ship you want, fly the way you want. 3: The music is awesome 4: Great sense of accomplishment once a task is done. 5: The universe is huge with lots of stuff to do! 6: Very modable.  Cons:  1: A bit glitchy at times. 2: The ingame tutorials arn't that useful. (But don't worry there are a ton of turtorial on the internet)  In all, Kerbal Space Program is a masterpiece, and one of my favorite games, definitely worth at full price.  9.8/10

One year ago, sentences like 'The space craft would stay in low earth orbit then go to moon' made no sense to me. I couldn't tell the difference between a single stage to orbit ship and a space station if my life depended on it. I would not believe someone who said you do not need to get escape velocity to go to the moon. I never really understood what it meant when people said apollo 11 had a orbiter and a lander separated and landed on the moon. I had no idea why space ships needed multiple stages or why it is a big deal to land the first stage back on earth.  Thanks to Kerbal Space Program (and Scott Manley (see his youtube videos if you haven't)) I now know how ignorant I was. Space always fascinated me, but I don't think short of studying orbital mechanics at a university, I would have ever learned about the awesome world of space travel if it wasn't for this game. Highly recommended for people who want to learn and do some hands on experiments. Also recommended for people who want to make crazy space ships and try (and fail) to get them to 'space'.
You can have a lots of fun with this game, but it can also be very frustrating if all your creations are just failing. As long as your patient the 20€ are well spent.  8.5/10

Best game I have ever played.  At first, I couldn't even get 10,000 Meters, or 10 KM in the sky. My rockets always exploded. But I learned, Built more complex staging arrays, and eventually got into orbit. I knew I was half way to the Mun.  I discovered how useful SRBs were (I used the Kickback Ones). Then I used the Mammoth Liquid fuel engine, and I set off for the Mun.  After I landed on the Mun, I landed on Minmus. Then I continued into the Solar System and landed on Duna.  In my opinion, Duna is the easiest planet to land on. The atmosphere's reentry does almost nothing to you, and Parachutes work on Duna.  However, in recent days, I could no longer load saved games.  10/10   And now, for the silly part.  First time playing: 'OMG Y IS MEH ROCKET EXPLODING WHY IS THERE FIRE'  400th Hour Playing: 'If I am correct, I will need 1700 m/s of Delta-V to reach Duna with the supplies in order for my colony of 32 kerbals to live.'

10/10   Would blow up kerbals again  EDIT 11/12/15: Now that the game is out of Early access, I can say this is a very interesting and fun game, Mainly because this (from what I know) hasn't really been attempted before, making this game unique. Let's start with the Building, It's fun. I love making original crafts and building one modeled of of real life aircraft/rockets. The game design is amazing and doesn't require a harddcore gaming PC to run which in a +5 in my books. The Gameplay is also fun, I love flying my rockets through the unevrase and exploring planets and flying planes in crazy ways and doing stunts in it. The main selling point though (apart from not needing a hardcore pc) are the mods, The mods add DAYS to the amount of time you can play the game, From making the game more realistic (FAR) or adding more parts to make new craft (B9 and Kax), The mods add more fun and creativity making this game an A+ in my books, ANd so far the only glitches I've EVER seen in this game was from mods not working together, and because of that, A+, 10 points from Griffendor, and TOP KEK.

What I liked about Kerbal Space Program is:  1. The amount of variation! a lot of games tend to get boring over-time and with KSP it's at it's slowest (if you mind repetitive games like me)  2. Statisfactory! this game has a lot of that, almost the most in any game I have ever played, like when first landing correctly on Duna or even the Mun, It's amazing, just look how other people have reacted to it, for fun.  3. Hard and sometimes unforgiving! This makes it a lot of fun, because planning you're flight in the hangar can be entertaining for hours, even planning it when you're not even playing the game. I'm a total beginner and I love this game. There's actual love involved with mutual recognition and buying presents for one another plus the occasional stepmotherly visits I'll endure. We're meant to be.  The game is buggy, wobbly and reminds me of the ArmA series which were just as wonky while still providing insane amounts of content and freedom of gameplay. Turns out that development is still ongoing and mods are stronk! with this one.  I have sent my first tourists into an orbital flight around Kerbin using a sleek rocket with fine-tuned solid fuel booster thrust and fuel load and applying a gravitation-assisted launch for the first time after reading about it. I've also managed to bring them back safely including all gathered scientific data with the entire final stage fully intact and parts of the spent stages recovered via the excellent mod 'Stage Recovery'.  I kept listening to liquid drum & bass while enjoying the orbit. Coincidentally, my pilot started dancing when the beat kicked in. This guy. I'm going to keep this guy.  I now have plans for finding an economical way of sending satellites into orbit for contract fulfilment, researching docking parts so I can start rescuing every stuck Kerbal from orbit, get close to the Mun, get to the Mun, get away from the Mun, then do so regularly while working on planes, my actual favorite. I achieved Mach 2 without supersonic tech unlocked only using generic jet engines which makes me proud as all hell. I'm also trying to develop a plane that can get to 18km altitude without relying too much on liquid fuel rocket engines so I can deploy it anywhere around the globe.  This game manages to keep me busy for days while also allowing for that short snack when I only have an hour to spend. There are tons of mods altering the game in every desirable way, from making it ♥♥♥♥-easy to making it ridiculously tough, from making it realistic to making it sci-fi. I've only yet installed the basics. Community seems dope. Devs seem dedicated. Game is so much fun if you're into the ol' preparation-execution-correction scheme. Friend told me to get it. Now I'm telling you to get it. Game's so worth it.  Time-consuming ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ though. Not good if you're meant to study or maintain a marriage.

This game will turn you into an astronaut rocket scientist. But be careful, it´s not easy.  Go take a look at the negative reviews a moment, see the pattern? Yea, those guys all washed out. They never made it though astronaut school. This game is a solid 10/10 instant classic that belongs in every collection. But is not for people with short attention spans, you need to be persistent, because you are going to fail over and over again until you learn the right way of doing things.  You are going to crash and burn a lot in the beginning, because this game works on real physics. You don´t just point the ship in the direction you want to go and hit the thrusters like most games. In this game, depending on your location, speed, and trajectory, it could take you years of game time just to turn your ship around, and that is assuming you have enough fuel to do that in the first place.  This game lets you take on every aspect of a space program, from rocket design, to figuring out your fuel allowance, to running the budget, all the way down to fine details like what astronauts to take on what missions, or what you want to name each individual rocket, and much more.  You can more or less do whatever you like. You can send up big rockets into orbit and other planets, you can turn the moon into a mining colony, you can capture asteroids, you can send out unmanned probes with countless scientific tools to loads of different locations and purposes, you can build rovers, planes, if you have enough imagination you can even build really insane things, like kinetic energy rod from god futuristic weapon satellites.  You start the game knowing nothing, and by the end you will be a fully qualified astronaut, mentally calculating how much delta v you need in order to escape the atmosphere for the payload you have, getting ready to burn prograde full-throttle at the apoapsis, setting up your maneuvers for a trajectory with a 2k close approach to your most favourite docking port.  One of my top 10 all time favorite games, 30+ years a gamer.

Awesome game and space simulation. Played it a little during early access but has come a long way since then, improving gameplay, features and physics. If space flight interests you, definetly get this. If building stuff interests you, check it out. Beneath the cute graphics there is a serious, challenging but fun simulation which when played in career mode really feels like your in the 'space race' of the sixties and then takes you into the modern day and beyond.... or you can just play in sandbox mode with all technologies unlocked.  There is no tutorial or in game help, but there is an extensive wiki and other useful information online (just google stuff). Essential things to google from the start (unless playing in Sandbox mode) are Biomes and how Science works and if you struggle with space planes there are some useful guides online.  KSP also supports community mods, of which there are many including graphics and physics overhauls, However, I am still playing full career using the base game and since the official release I feel the physics are very good without mods. However I do use a number of mods which do not alter gameplay but provide some very usefull features. The developers did a great job of making the game very accesible, but as you progress some of these become essential really.   KERBAL ENGINEER Provides extra information on all sorts of things, some of which is even essential I would say. Some of this is replicated my MechJeb, but I still like some of the features and presentation of Kerbal Engineer.  PRECISE NODE (not sure compatible anymore and MechJeb has same feature anyway) Allows easier and more precise editing of maneuver nodes (once you unlock them by upgrading your space centre buildings) plus displays extra information about the new orbits that will be achieved following the maneuver.  DOCKING PORT ALIGNMENT / NAVBALL DOCKING ALIGNMENT Both provide graphical docking aids, very useful (once you have researched docking ports).  MECHJEB Once you find your tired of doing the same maneuvers over and over again, this mod automates many common maneuvers. The technolgy must be researched first and part included on your ships, so is still realistic as these are just features you would have available anyway.  STAGE RECOVERY If your playing on full career this is very useful to help recover jettisoned stages (and save money). The base game has a number of limitations in this area making recovery of jettiosned stages difficult or impossible at times (you have no control over when chutes are deployed once jettisoned and jettisoned parts are deleted once 2.5 km away from your main space craft). You still need to have enough parachutes mounted and will only recover parts which would actualy return to Kerbin (Earth) safely.

TL;DR Buy the game whenever possible (Prefferably on sale to save money as its kinda expensive)  Pros: Easily modded Constantly updated Runs well Can play with or without mods Is closely involved with the community Easily learnable controls Teaches you about science without you knowing (is this technically a con?)  Cons: Textures aren't the best could be improved Very large learning curve Highly Addictive Massive frame drops when building large crafts A bit expensive but worth the price  My judgment:  May not say I have many hours but I played this before I got it on steam, I have roughly 500+ hours in the game and it is one of the best if not the best sandbox game ever. Modding support is one of the most embraced things in the game, it is not like gmod or games like that were mods are needed to play and its never updated, this is why its so good.   You can create some awesome things without mods and some even cooler things with mods. The texture quality isnt bad but could be improved. Multiple mods have been supported so much they have been included into the game, examples are the mk2 expansion and the sub assemblies mod. The best part about this is that even the mod developers have been employed to make the game.

Synopsis: My rating of this game would be a 8.5/10, because of the creative potential, mods, community, and knowledge gained from playing the game.  This game, like many others that I had baught in 2014, is a very deep and special game to me. Ever since I first got KSP in 2014, I have been playing it almost non-stop and trust me, I enjoy it thuroughly. Although there may be some snags in the coding or crashes due to CPU usage or RAM overusage, the Squad team really did it with the previous update and have finally released a stable, smooth, and stronger 64-bit, which, I should mention, may scratch out many of the negative comments about the game on how the game used to constantly crash for CPU or RAM usage.   Don't get me wrong, this game CAN... repeat, CAN... get repetative. If, let's say, you want to go to a far planet then you take a bunch of fuel tanks and a nuclear engine and go there quite easily, which can degrade the 'fin' of the game; Yet, that's where breaks come in. As of recently, I took a rather long break from KSP and I finally realized then that it had become a very important part of me.  On to a side note,  KSP can be absolutely fantastic for crude education in Aerospace engineering. Someone in KSP will learn some simple terms such as 'Delta V' or 'Prograde', 'Retrograde', 'Antinormal', 'Normal' etc. Someone playing KSP will learn concepts of how rockets work, how boosters work, and how flow of air works. An example, is when someone makes a lander to go to the Mun or somewhere farther, they will soon learn why exactly Saturn VII used the fairing between the mothership and the lander; Or the player will learn soon enough that a square is less Aerosynamic than an Elipsoid. With the new 1.2 update coming around the corner, a player of KSP will also soon learn that Radio communication is essential, and will learn how exactly a 'Satelite Constelation' is essential to ANY kind of mission to space.   In all honesty, I'd rate this game a solid 8.5/10, due to it's engaging atmosphere (Pls get the reference ;-;), potential for creativity, knowledge, and community. The only downside is, When I got the game I was hoping for a more 'procedural' solar system, for a bit of a challenge, or even Star Systems that one could travel to. I also expected to see the modding community as a friendly one, but I realized that if you make one wrong click, then your 'mod page' will become an endless list of bug reports. Don't get me wrong, though, the mods are to die for (On the Mun). If the developers could keep up with Space Engineers, though, then I'd rate the game a 9/10 (SE gets updated every Thursday for thos of you who don't know).

Addictive and so much fun.   Some people still have trouble with the game crashing. It's not about graphics, it's about physics and for some reason this game was designed to run on the cpu, which is crazy. I'm running and amd fx-8100, 2x geforce gt760, 32gbs ram and it crashed every 20 minutes from overheating. To solve the crashing you gotta force the gpu.  In steam, right click on KSP and choose properties. Click Launcher Options and type in -force-opengl  Bam! Solved.

I was in trouble. While under no immediate threat, my top pilot was stranded in space. It was early-game, and his ship had run out of fuel mid-de-orbit. He stayed there, stranded, for one hundred days, as I had given up hope.  Later, I was flipping through the 'funny' KSP reviews, and I was having a good time, laughing about all this funny stuff. I've got at least 150 hours in pre-Steam Release versions, so I still understood most of it. Then, I saw it: 'get out and push'. Eureka! I load up the game, take my pilot out of the capsule, and use his EVA jetpack to push the ship backwards, slowly driving his orbit into the atmosphere. I'm in luck, too: his jetpack has infinite fuel as long as I get back to the capsule before it uns out. After minutes of this routine, he falls through the atmosphere. Re-entry is a serious obstacle, so his whole ship falls apart during atmospheric entry. Finally, the capsule lands with one parachute out of three intact.  Everything was destroyed, but the pilot survived. Mission success. Physics has saved him, and he now pursues a proud career in aeronautics (or died, I can't remember).

This one is great for either a casual gamer or then to those 'nerdy' geeks who want to push the envelope of creativity and loved their technics lego's and kits. This is essentially space lego sim with astronauts without the lego blocky looks. Very complex things are underneath the bonnet of this one though but I like the way it's all there for you to play with, but not necessary to frustrate yourself about, if you like just experimenting haphazardly. You can really go from simple lighting up a few 'firecrackers' rocket mechanics all the way to understanding calculations and orbits, re-entry's etc. And the feeling is great with humor. While the mechanics allow complexity, the game does not take itself too seriously. I really do think this is simulator type and kind of wish a more arcadey game mode was there with a more linear plot and missions to go through with story and characters. That would obviously be an addition to already the game modes that exist. No point fixing what ain't broken. But for me after a while it does seem to get a little boring because simulators tend to be that way you know? I do like simulators though. Recommended! Kerbal Space Program is just pure fun. Pretty much that, I don't think I need to expand on that statement, I could leave my review at that.  There's nothing better than tossing a bunch of parts together in sandbox mode and trying to figure out from scratch how you plan to get to space, learning how orbits works and other cool sciency stuff.  You start by making a really messy rocket, toss a few boosters underneath a casule, cross fingers and hope for the best. I initally learnt how to play through trial and error and then you realise the game has mod support and spend countless hours downloading part packs and other joyous things to add into the mix like warp drives, SpaceX style reusability and a fully scaled realistic solar system.  The game isn't fantastically optimised but it's definitely better than what it used to be, building a giant behemoth of a ship in orbit, docking it together piece by piece and obsevering as the FPS counter crawls to a halt still makes you feel proud of what you've constructed. And it's not just rockets you can build, the game has a full suite of aircraft parts for building passenger planes, shuttles and SSTO craft.  Kerbal is just a whole load of fun, 'nough said!

- Draw supercomplex futuristic ships and plan Ares-like ('the martian') missions - Get excited - Launch KSP - Start building a superduper complex lander for Duna w/ aerobraking, atmospheric re-entry, chutes, skycrane, reaction control systems - Wonder how to fit that ♥♥♥♥ on a rocket powerful enough - Get into orbit (eventually) - Miss your launch windows - 'Well, what's 2 years in kerbal time, let's fast forward!' - See you forgot solar panels for the long trip - Run out of batteries - 'Well I'll deal with that later' - Warp time ahead, at least 15 minutes to wait in game.  - 'Ho i'm gonna do something else' - Start building a plane - It does'nt fly - Try a new mod for flying planes - It does'nt fly. - Decide it's time to explore kerbin - But you need a plane that flies. - 'Land' on island runway. - 'Cool, I can visit'. Visit.  - Remember you're in sandbox, so yeah, no point in exploring. - It's 4 am - Close KSP - Repeat.  11/10 -> -1 for the time lost ; +1 'cos I don't care.

Thanks squad!  ------------------------------------------------  I absolutley love this game but I have to give it a negative review. Here is why: Update .90 rolls around, my performance is awesome. Lots of graphical mods everything looks great and everything runs like a dream.  Update 1.1 rolls around boasting it's performance boosts up the wazoo. I see many youtubers videos backing up this claim. I open the game and get framerates which are far below playable. I get 7-8 fps on the menu. THE MENU. I lowered every setting as low as it can go, Making the game look like potato. I achieve a performance boost of about 2 fps average.  I do run an AMD cpu which is the issue. But I have not had the issue in the past. I understand that the game went through an engine change but us AMD users are people too.  For those intrested in my specs: CPU: AMD FX-6300 Vishera 6-core RAM: 16GB DDR3 OS: Win7 Pro 64bit Videocard: GTX 960  I should mention that I now have a GTX 1070 and have seen no performance improvement, I figured as such because the game us cpu bound.  Hopefully this gets resolved since I don't want to rebuild my pc just to play ksp. I'll just play beta .90 until then. If you feel like you can help me out shoot me a comment. Thanks!

Kerbal Space Program will teach you by making you try, fail, try again and succeed.   After you've spent some time with the Kerbals, you'll understand orbital mechanics in a way that used to be only available to the priviledged few who were either smart enough to understand it from Earth, or got to try it for themselves in space. You'll understand (seriously understand) what it took to get to the Moon, what it will take to get to Mars, and beyond.  If this is what real space travel is like, you can see why NASA is so passionate about it. Every Earthling should own a copy of this game.

Probably my no 1 game  If you're looking for a game to really get your teeth into, this is it! Just look at the hours played of most reviewers. Unlike some other games with a lot of hours behind them, this one isn't grindy, this is 600+ hours of me figuring stuff out enjoying the learning process.   I have also never played anything as open world as this, especially with the amazing modding community. Thanks to that I have spent hours building satellite relay networks, building self sustaining space colonies and hauling large meteors into orbit to attach to my space station. It reminds me of the worlds I created in my mind as a kid playing Lego.  Something else that makes this game unique is that what makes it fun and challenging is real world physics (to be pedantic - scaled and tweaked to make it fun)  To those that get stuck in the beginning, try search for tutorial videos by Scott Manley on youtube. They are not just tutorials, they are really entertaining too, and will get you to 'fly safe'

Also a small smattering of science. What's not to love? Build a perfect rocket. Build an over engineered rocket. Make a replica of the space shuttle. Build a space station out of nothing but docking ports and struts. Bounce a kerbal off Minmus. Whatever!  Play a good space sim not seen since the days of Microsoft Space Simulator. It's a good game!

INT. MISSION CONTROL ROOM  A group of TECHNICIANS sit at a row of computers. They are monitoring a space flight. A WHITE HAIRED MAN stands behind one of them, he is pitched forward slightly so as to read one of the displays. Mounted on the wall in front of them are two large displays. The first is showing a flat projection of the earth and tracing the orbit of a space vehicle with a 38 degree inclination. The second is currently blank. Behind the operators are seated three senior ranked MILITARY MEN.   WHITE HAIRED MAN I'm patching it to the White House and Buckingham Palace. I'm sure Her Majesty will be fascinated!   TECHNICIAN ONE We have audio-visual.   MILITARY MAN ONE Ahh, at last!  The second screen switches on, initially only static is seen and heard. The video feed gradually dissolves in. We see JAMES BOND and HOLLY GOODHEAD in a lover's embrace. They are floating in zero-G, bedsheets hang from their forms in an inexplicably one-G manner. The control room gasps in unison.   MILITARY MAN ONE (to himself) double-o seven...   MILITARY MAN TWO My God! What's Bond doing?   WHITE HAIRED MAN I think he's attempting re-entry, sir!   TECHNICIAN ONE Actually, I think he's attempting an orbital insertion, sir!   TECHNICIAN TWO I think you'll find that's an Oberth maneuver.  The TECHNICIANS giggle. MILITARY MAN ONE glares at them disapprovingly.   TECHNICIAN THREE He should be thrusting retrogra-  MILITARY MAN ONE stands up, clearly fuming, and points towards the door.   MILITARY MAN ONE Get out!  TECHNICIAN THREE stands and walks towards the door. He glances backwards at his co-workers who are still stifling laughs. JAMES BOND looks in the direction of the camera and becomes aware that their tryst is being broadcast. BOND's surprised facial expression is quickly replaced by a BENNY HILL-like grin. He switches off the camera.

Spaceships, spaceships, spaceships!   Imagine a box full of Lego spaceships parts. Got it? Now build a rocket ship.   So i've played this game a bit yet in a sense Kerbal isn't much more than this. One game mode gives you an unlimited box of parts (sandbox), another makes you unlock them via science research and one lets you research the parts  and  earn  then  cash to buy the parts (career).  Learning the game mechanics to plan orbits is a little tricky for some but perservation and youtube is your friend.  Finally, mod support (not via Steam) is the Jam filling, Icing and Cherry on the top. There are  hundreds  of mods adding new parts, interface windows, missions, worlds, graphics, tech...  You get the idea!  A wonderful, wonderful game and one I will remember fondly 20 years from now

First a word of warning, this game has a very steep learning curve! Before you even realise you're learning whilst playing this game you will have learned about gravity turns, hohman transfers, prograde and retrograde orbits, etc, etc! While it is possible to play this game entirely through trial and error before long you will probably look up the delta V equation (Tsiolkovsky rocket equation) and more in depth orbital mechanics, then you will be well on your way to learning the basics of rocket science! Don't worry though the hardest parts of rocket science are left out of the game (materials science, chemistry of rocket fuels etc)  Recreate real space missions or go and colanise Mun, the choices are endless with three game modes to choose from you'll rarely be stuck for something to do. I really cant recommend this game enough!

Want to:  - Design, build, and fly your own rockets, satellites, space stations, and moon bases?  - See if you can replicate the accomplishments of the Gemini or Apollo Programs?  - Gather science, research rocket technologies, and execute complex missions on faraway planets?  - Design and implement complex ComSat networks? - Learn lots about orbital mechanics and something called delta-V?  - Play a game with a highly active mod community?    You found it. There is a reason this game has a 97-98% approval rating.

This is a game for creative and strategic minds, you will have the chance run your own space program where you will build spacecrafts as simple or as complex as you want or need.  In carreer mode you will be in charge of all the areas of your space program, this means you will have to take care of recruiting and training new engineers, scientists, and pilots, accepting new contracts, building the spaceships, choosing the right crew members, pilot the spaceships, run experiments to gain new knowledge and use it to research new parts, you'll also have to manage your space program's financial resources.  If you expect to fight aliens and protect the world from evil, this game is not for you. KSP is a game in which your only enemy OR your best friend is the laws of physics.  With the wide range of mods available from the huge KSP comunity, you can make your gaming experience as complicated or as simple as you desire. You'll find excellent mods that improve the visuals, add environment sound effects, add new parts to the game, add and AI pilot to your spaceship or airplane, provide flight assistance, and much more.  If you are only interested in building and piloting your creations with no limits, you can also do that in the samdbox mode.  One thing worth mentioning is that you must be prepared to learn physics principles in order to have any chance of surviving, this is not a game that depends on your speed with te keyboard and mouse, but it depends a lot on your knowledge, planning, strategy, and execution. One amazing resource is the wikipedia-style documentation available in the game, and of course, youtube videos.

Kerbal Space Program is THE prototype of a successful indie game, and argueably one of the best space exploration games. 'But why?', you may ask. And this why I'm writing this review here.  The short answer is, 'Because space is awesome!' but I'm not here to give short answers. The real thing is, this game takes the math-filled boring science stuff that lies behind the concept of space travel and hides it behind an easy-accessible and fun environment: A rocket that leaves the ground is built in a matter of minutes. Only a short click on the 'launch' button and a bunch of death-defying kerbonauts makes their way towards space... only to find that they are coming back sooner than expected. The wonderful thing is, that the nature of the game encourages the player to use trial and error. If you don't get far enough into space, add moar boosters, if the whole rocket wobbles like a flying worm, add moar struts. What would cost billions of dollars (and probably many people's lives) in real life is every day work in KSP: if your flight didn't work quite as intended, just hit 'revert' and that whole thing never happened, except you can now try to fix what was wrong before and take another shot.  But the best part is, although your green companions' comic reactions will make every fatal disfunction of your vessel hilarous as hell, there is a lot of serious business behind the game - Although trial and error will eventually get you to your goal, your missions are going to be a lot more successful if you understand the physics of this game, which closes the cycle: the game makes you WANT to know all that math-filled boring science stuff that lies behind the concept of space travel I mentioned earlier. And surprisingly, it is a lot more satisfying to return from a successful mission if your calculations told you beforehand that it should work.  Plus, its career mode will always provide you with fun challenges that go beyond 'Land on object XY'. Building space stations, deploying satellites, taking surveys, redirecting or landing asteroids, etc. are possibly objectives of the contracts that fund your space program. So if you always wanted to manage your very own space program, this is the perfect game for you.  And if you still not have enough, that game has one of the liviest communities I've seen so far. Hundreds of mods already exist and if you'll ever feel like anything should be added, there's a 99% chance a mod that implements that already exists.  TL;DR: It's a wonderful, easy-accessible, fun and actually educating game that really outstands in a time where soulless shooters are the majority.  DEFINITELY A 10/10.

I've spent more time playing this $40 indie game than the next 10 games in my Steam library combined. Some nerds will complain that it oversimplifies physics, but Kerbal Space Program simulates the important stuff accurately enough that even NASA has endorsed it as an entry-level school educational program for learning the basics about things like orbital mechanics, asteroid interception, and other space stuff.  Build space stations, build science colonies on and around other planets, build asteroid refueling depots, build ludicrous 1000-part atmospheric jets, or build elegant 50-part recreations of Apollo 11. The possibilities in KSP are almost endless, especially if you start using mods.  A high-end CPU is required in order to simulate the complex physics involved in hundreds of ship components interacting in real-time. You'll want at least a relatively modern desktop Intel i3 or i5 in order to run it well. Entry-level and midrange laptop users will likely have a hard time running KSP without slowdowns. On the plus side, it's not very demanding on your GPU, so just about any graphics card will run it fine.  Squad, KSP's developer, is an indie studio and this comes with a lot of obligatory jank. There are many long-standing bugs, quirks, and limitations that can be mostly worked around once you know about them, but the first time you encounter them they might be a real headache. The most recent versions of KSP have had a strong focus on bugfixing though, and hopefully Squad will continue to maintain this in the future.  KSP has a rather steep learning curve. Without consulting guides, it will likely take tens of hours before your first successful orbit, and much longer before you'll have a hope of tackling more challenging objectives like landing on other planets. Fortunately even failure is almost always fun in KSP. This is a game with legs - it's not your typical $60 AAA title where you have a tightly-scripted 5-10 hour campaign and then never play it again.  There's been some controversy lately about Squad's development practices, with a number of high-profile developers recently leaving the project, so the years of continuous development KSP's been through might be at an end. This is worrying, though a good portion of the game's userbase has actually expressed a measure of relief that the game's frequent updates slowing or ending altogether might mean mods will stop bring broken so frequently. I think KSP still has lots of untapped potential and it's sold millions of copies, so I'm hopeful that the people at Squad who write the checks will start properly compensating the developers responsible for its continuing success and continue expanding the game's scope in line with their promises.  Even if 1.2 is the last version we get, it's still a great product. There's lots of possible things I dream of doing in KSP that I still lack the skill to achieve. Maybe after another 300 hours.

For example : It offers the ability to build a ship that can go all the way to a gas planet and visit it's moon's which have atmospheres and oceans, buuuuuuut  oceans will almost always kill you due to their non-refinement.  Examined by the oceans audio and visual effects, it appears to be still in an alpha state - ie, it's extremely loud (rip headphone users), and your whole ship will disappear in a multitude of splashes - no survivability whatso ever, at almost any given speed. So yea, there's that....  I'd greatly, GREATLY, with pleasure in my heart, recommend this game, if major changes were just made to fix those problems.  But for now I only just a little bit recommend it - entering an atmosphere going 5000 feet per second, is very cool and the physics is a sight to see (when it works) - ie I've loved playing this game and following through with complex failures, and the learning curve, though steep, has been overall, a wonderful learning experience.  Although one thing I really need to point out, this game is recognized as 'finished' and I gotta say, it is not finished, and does not need to cost more than 15 dollars, as it pretty much crashes on any machine from lack of patches

Not saying you shouldn't buy this game, but I'd say consider waiting for a bit more before you get disappointed.  Community is still going strong, which I love, modders release interesting and fun mods, and developers are still working hard on it, which also another good, healthy sign. Has everything sandbox needs; freedom and creativity. The only limit is the space and your creativity. Unity 4 was problematic, trust me, I tried Unity 4 before as well. With Unity 5 update, I can run KSP on my laptop just fine with minimal lag.  Now, been playing it since 0.16, and the only reason I say I do not recommend this is the stability of the current version. 0.16 up to 1.1, it went nice and smooth, the only problem was the amount of RAM this game was taking. Other than that, I had fun making space stations, Mun bases, orbit around the Kerbin, and even attaching multiple SRBs on a chair and watch a Kerman break through a sound barrier. Due to the circumstances, I had to put my computers away from myself; and I came back, have my KSP updated to 1.1.2, and with the new version, I am fighting through the game just to make a single ground vehicle and test it around the facility.  For those who are still wondering, I'll simulate a day of me and KSP.  I startup KSP, resume a saved game, and I go to the Spaceplane Hanger, open up a saved vehicle, the replica of HEMTT M978A4. I continue work on it, and I save it often, how often? After I place a single part. Why you may ask, and I answer, because I don't know when the game will crash on me, and I don't want to start over, or even, have my file broken and does not recognize my vehicle as a whole, but as a floating part.  Here we are, on the runway, ready to test this vehicle. Spend lots and lots of time and effort, I hope this works. I press the forward key, the vehicle goes backward. Interesting, my wheel settings are fine. Goes back to tracking station and comes back, ah, now it goes forward. Few seconds later, whole game freezes and tells me there is a dump file. Goes around the forum and threads, people are having simlar issues, some worse than mine.  Really, I try not to give any negative feedback on this game, but the game itself is screaming at me to give negative feedback. I still love the game, and I say you should definitley give it a shot(If you can be patient and go through all the crashes and bugs, that is).  And now that the original creator left the project(and I am sure they have a new lead project manager), I fear that the pace of update/new contents will slow down, which I hope not to happen.  Overall, as an aerospace engineer, this is something I love LOve LOVE to play, and you should try this. BUT, before you buy this, think of what you will encourter; stability of the game and number of bugs in the game. Are you willing to pay the price to be patient and go through all the hassle other players going through? Or will it be yet another game that stays in your library and never get played for at least couple of months/years? The choice is yours.

This once great orbital mechanics simulator has fallen victim to a failed development cycle that has introduced broken physics that have rendered the game unplayable for too long.  I've been to the Mun and built stations and bases more times than I can count. I've been to Minmus and Duna, but have spent the vast majority of my 900+ hours working stations and bases. I've used more mods than I can count, including MechJeb, KIS KAS, alarm clock, FASA, KW, contract mods out the ying yang, ScanSat, Spacey, MKS, OKS, TAC ls and many many more.  I've been playing since 0.25 and up until now, bugs were minor and you could get around them.  Recently, however, even with the 1.1.3 patch, there are simply too many problems with the underlying physics that lead to in game problems that are unpredictable and game-ruining.   I could also complain about the never-ending mod break/fix cycle, but that's not why I'm giving a thumbs down. Someobdy broke the basic mechanics of the game and it's been like that for a while. Up until then, this game was marvelous. Now it's just about waiting for the next surprise to ruin several hours worth of planning and playing. Fun exited the equation somewhere along the way.   Example? Sure. Create a station with a small docking port on the side. Put it in orbit around Mun. Create a small ship and dock. Watch the whole thing tumble out of the sky as the orbit deteriorates in a matter of minutes for no discerbable reason. This is my most recent encounter with the broken physics in the game - right after the latest patch (1.1.3)  Many such 'surprise adventures' have ruined this game, at least for me.   There is talk of a Unity update to fix underlying engine problems. I would wait until then.  If you want more info, read the current 1.1.3 release thread on the forums. Much truth is to be had there.

I'd like to start by saying that i absolutely love Kerbal space program, so much so i have once again sat at my computer searching forums trying to find a solution to the terrible game breaking stuttering that plagues my current save. through my searches i have discovered the issue lies somewhere between unity and SQUADS own programming, ( i'm no programmer i dont understand it). Then the problems begin. I really want to like this game, but I find playing it an exercise in extreme frustration, eventually leading to flat out anger. On the plus side, it is the best avenue for teaching the mechanics of spaceflight I have ever seen. I still credit playing this for my current understanding of orbital mechanics, before I had very little concept of the quirks of periapsis vs apoapsis, etc.  The problem is this game is deeply flawed, almost to the point of being unplayable. How people manage to have the patience to build these ridiculous sprawling space creations is beyond me. Most of the time if I build my own rocket, it blows up, which is funny the first time or two. Then I just want to see something FLY WITHOUT EXPLODING. This would be excusable if either they gave some significant help in building rockets, or had a very good avenue for downloading working craft, but they have neither. The tutorial is barely adequate, and the forums online for downloading craft are a sorry, poorly documented and maintained joke. More than half the time if I download a craft it doesn't work either, and comes with ZERO documentation on how to use it. Also, trying to figure out how their tinker toys building system works is extremely confusing. Often I've built something and have little idea how to add something in the middle of the rocket, or tell it which part is the 'root' properly. I like the idea, but the execution is anything but user-friendly.  This is before I even get to the glitches. It's as if they decided sometime during the alpha software development stage 'eh, good enough,' and then rushed the game to market rather than finish their product. Very commonly while trying to adjust my orbit during time warp, it will suddenly decide to drastically change the orbital characteristics, forcing me to use valuable delta-v to correct what is essentially an infuriating bug. This game also DESPERATELY needs a built-in autopilot. You can add one on (which I think is absolutely necessary, I use MechJeb), but I think such a feature should be native. Asking people to 'wing it' with trajectories and orbital mechanics is the most absurd concept I have ever heard of. Would you have expected the Apollo astronauts to figure out orbital rendezvous by the seat of their pants? Could it be done, maybe, but it's an unnecessary and extremely tedious waste of time, adding pointless difficulty.  Not only that, there is little of interest to do. Maybe this is just because I've stuck with sandbox mode, but only thing I can think to do is fly to some planet and land, then often I have to start planning the 'rescue' mission when the lousy craft doesn't fly the way it should and strands my kerbal on Duna or wherever. Just flying is enjoyable enough, but I'd have a lot more fun if I didn't have to work around the lousy interface, the shoddy craft, and the incessant glitches manifesting themselves when you least want to put up with them.  in summation, this is an interesting but extremely frustrating half-finished game that needs a lot more work to be properly playable in an enjoyable fashion.

tl;dr: Could be the best game ever, but still plagued with crippling bugs.  Is this game fun? Yes. Is it wildly addicting? Yes. Does it make you think in new and creative ways? Yes. So, why then the thumbs down?  I have been playing this game since version 1.7(ish). I have followed its development with joy, and enjoyed being a part of the community. The nearly 400 hours I have logged are just on the Steam version, I also have tons of hours on the version I bought direct from the developer. The features are great, all the new additions have added depth, and everything has really goes well for this game...except for one thing...  It's still buggy beyond belief. I don't run mods at all. I think 0.23 was the last version I ran any because I got tired of the problems. This game is still SO jammed full of bugs I wish they would spend a release fixing all of the universe-breaking problems and put out a truly stable release.  This may be the fault of the Unity engine, it may be the fault of the community demand for big features in every release, or it may be something else. The fact remains that it is still almost a guarantee that building something only moderately complex will result in a buggy mission that you will be lucky to finish without reloading. Even the simple act of building a ship can destroy the VAB interface to where you can't even place parts right at times.  I love this game, but it's maddeningly glitchy. I play it on a moderately powered PC, a non-gaming laptop, and a Mac, and have access to both the Steam and direct versions; there is no difference. The Kraken seems to not discrimiate against any version.  I have to give this game a thumbs-down simply for the slew of bugs that continue to haunt it even after so much development. Any game that requires this much reloading I don't feel is worthy of a 1.0 release. It should have remained in early-access until it was at least stable enough to play regularly without banging your face on your desk.  Perhaps I'm just unlucky and the Kraken has a taste for my blood.

After so many years in Alpha and Beta this game has too far to go to recommend still.  Aerodynamics just made their way in and vehicle control is worse than ever despite promises to increase control and realism.  There are still hundreds of issues attaching parts together and parts just randomly deciding not to stick when you load a ship. They are just now starting to add in types of pieces that actually fit together without your craft looking like it came from the scrap pile.  The campaign is frustrating as can be because of the control issues mentioned above. You will try to make your way into orbit only to find out something didn't connect properly, something broke or for some unexplainable reason you can't do what you want to do and have spent hours setting up. Research is tedious and many of the challenges/milestones you must reach to complete it are completly out of the question unless you can find a handful of mods to make it playable.  5/10. Might be a good game given a few more years. Great humor and quirky characters.

I can't in good conscience recommend a game that can this easily wipe your progress. If you think you've autosaved and you haven't, autoload will irrevocably take you back *arbitrarily many missions ago* to the last time you autosaved. This is basic stuff here.

Buy this game. You can design and test rockets, planes, spacestations and probes. Its all very trial and error with cute green little aliens. There are neither goals, nor predefined game paths or endings. Just build and fly stuff trough space.  You should check out the Kerbal Spaceport. There are so many great mods (although the game ist still in development) which offer your more parts, more realism, tools, you name it.  Best 20 EUR I spent on a game lately.  -- added after release  The game idea is great but I don't thing the developer delivered a finished product. Playing it, I always feel like there could be more. You want to be exact with your rockets and spaceships, your orbits and landings but the game does not give you enough numbers to calculate. Well get a mod. Some important parts are missing. Well get a mod. There is no remote control. Well get a mod. But here the problems start. There are so many mods, they are all somewhat interdependent, there are dlls you need as a basis for certain mods. Updates break mods. It's excruciating. I am not buying a game so I can spend days putting it together with mods.  This could have been a great game with more care, some more realism, better instruments and so forth. But instead you end up in mod hell. It is worse than Skyrim or Fallout NV. It is such a shame, I was looking forward to the release but the progress disappointed me more and more.  The second thing that really bugs me is this: You start out by shooting a manned capsule into space and later you research stuff like probes, batteries etc. The tech progression is just wrong. It so bugs me. I know it is a design choice but I would prefer a more realistic approach. There is a mod though (with all the caveats that come with mods...e.g. it's not working well).  In it's current state I would not recommend the game. The sandbox mode is fun if you like building. But the career mode just sucks. And honestly only playing sandbox is boring. It's like minecraft in creative mode (well many people have fun with that, my wife included, but it is not for all)  YES: for people who love tinkering with mods and enjoy sandbox games NO: people who like finished products and a progressing gameplay
